Tags: 2fa duo Duo-bypass-code duo-mobile-app duo-phone-call duo-push byui-duo-security-key duo-passcodes duo-hardware-tokens duo-biometrics duo-touch-id duo-face-id duo-windows-hello duo-security-key byui-duo how-to-use-duo-byui
Paragraphs: Summary    This guide provides an overview of all the two-factor authentication (2FA) methods currently supported by BYU-Idaho through Duo. These methods offer enhanced security for accessing your accounts and services. By utilizing these diverse 2FA methods, you can ensure your accounts and data remain secure while enjoying the flexibility of choosing the authentication method that best suits your needs.    Duo Push    Description: Duo Push sends a notification to the Duo Mobile app on your smartphone or tablet. Approve the login request with a single tap.    How to Use:    App Generated Passcodes    Description: Generate passcodes with the Duo Mobile app, even offline.    How to Use:    SMS Passcodes    Description:Â Log in using a passcode received from Duo in a text message. When you land on the text message page, it will show that a text message was just sent to you with a passcode. When you receive the message, enter that passcode into the space provided and click or tap Verify to log in to the application. When authenticating from a mobile device in the United States and Canada your browser may automatically enter the passcode for you. If you did not receive the text message from Duo, use the Send a new passcode link to try sending it again.Â Passcodes received in a text message expire when used.    How to Use:    Phone Call Approval    Description: Authenticate via phone callback. Answer the phone call from Duo and follow the voice instructions to log in to the application.    How to Use:    Hardware Token Passcodes    Description: This is a legacy authentication method that was used previously. These were offered by BYU-Idaho as an alternative 2FA method when more practical options weren't availableğŸ —ğŸ —Hardware token are small keyfob0like devices that allow users to enter the passcode generated from the device.ğŸ —ğŸ —BYU-Idaho only supports this supports this authentication method for legacy users.    How to Use:    Biometrics (Touch ID, Face ID, Windows Hello)    Description: BYU-Idaho supports biometric authentication methods that are integrated into your device for secure access to applications and services.Â These methods include Touch ID and Face ID for iOS and macOS users, Android Biometrics for Android users, and Windows Hello on Windows devices, and Android biometrics.    How to Use:    Security Keys    Description: Security keys are hardware devices used for authentication that enhance security by requiring physical possession of the key to access systems and applications. These keys provide a robust second factor method, ensuring that even if passwords are compromised, unauthorized access is prevented without the physical key.    How to Use:    Bypass Code    Description: If you're ever locked out of Duo and your other authentication methods have failed, the IT Service Desk can assist you by providing a temporary Bypass Code."ğŸ —ğŸ —These bypass codes are temporary and expire within a brief period after they're generated by the IT Service Desk.    How to Use:    Additional Resources    For detailed instructions on setting up and using each of these 2FA methods, please refer to the Duo Universal Prompt Guide.

Header: New BYUI Mac Issued Computer FAQ
Tags: computer-replacement new-computer requesting-a-new-computer need-new-computer Old-Computers transfer-files replacing-old-computers new-mac new-macbook new-byui-mac
Paragraphs: Getting a New BYUI Issued Computer    Â     What do I need to do?    Once you have received theÂ email regarding your computer replacement, please follow the steps below.    Before appointment:Â Â     Schedule appointmentÂ here    Plan on one hour for the appointment.Â     Back up all of your files via campus-supported OneDrive or by your own meansÂ     Your Web Browserâ€™s Bookmarks will only transfer if you sign in to the browser and sync them before receiving your new computer.Â Â     Ensure you have your device and all chargers or docking stations that came with it. Bring all equipment to the appointment.Â         After replacementÂ Â     Install additional software as needed and ensure that the new computer has your data that was backed up previously by you.Â     If needed, log in to your web browser such as Chrome and Firefox to access your previously backed up bookmarks.Â     What does Tech Support do?    At the date/time you've selected, we will meet you in your office specified in the appointment and get you logged in and set up on your new campus computer.Â     We will log you into the computer and go over the following items with you according to your needs:Â     Do I have to be there when the technician comes to replace my computer?    Do I need to back up files?    Yes, you are responsible for backing up any files from your old laptop to your new one. If you use OneDrive, we can help sign you into OneDrive on the new machine during your appointment.Â     Backing upâ€¯your files to something like OneDrive stores the files in a cloud location where they are available even if you do not have access to your physical computer. Highly recommended as a way to ensure you donâ€™t lose files/data if something unexpected happens to your physical computer.â€¯Take a look atâ€¯Accessing OneDriveâ€¯for a walk throughâ€¯on backing up your files.Â     What if I forgot some files?    We hold onto computers for 2 weeks after they are replaced in case there are files missing.Â     Contact us if you find you are missing files/programs/etcÂ     What computer am I receiving?    You will be receiving a similar computer to the type you have currently. For example, if you currently have a MacBook Pro, you will be receiving an updated MacBook Pro, unless you have already made different arrangements with the I.T. department.Â     If youâ€™re not sure what new computer we have for you, please call the Tech Support Projects team at x9036.Â     What happens to my old computer?    We hold onto it for 2 weeks to ensure there are no files that you end up needing off of itÂ     We then wipe the machine and either reissue as a trickle computer or send it to Surplus SalesÂ Â     If interested in purchasing your old computer, make a note of the asset tag and keep in contact with Surplus Sales for when they receive that device so you can purchase it.Â     With hundreds of different computers being replaced each year, we are unable assist in tracking where your computer goes.Â     Can I keep my old computer after my new one is delivered to make sure everything is working?    Your data should be backed up before the appointment with IT, so this should not be needed.Â     If you feel this is still needed, approval will need to be given from the IT manager over the Tech Support Projects team. To request this permission, contact the projects team atÂ technologysupportprojects@byui.eduÂ or call x9036.Â     What if I am retiring at the end of this year?    Who do I call for help/assistance with my new computer?

Header: New BYUI Windows Issued Computer FAQ
Tags: computer-replacement new-computer requesting-a-new-computer need-new-computer Old-Computers migration transfer-files replacing-old-computers new-windows-computer
Paragraphs: Getting a New BYUI Issued Computer    Â     What do I need to do?    Once you have received theÂ email regarding your computer replacement, please followÂ steps below.    Before appointment:Â Â     Schedule appointmentÂ here        Leave computer in your office on campus, powered on and plugged into power and networkÂ     Have your old computer, charger and docking station in your office in time for your appointment.Â     After replacementÂ Â     Log into new computer (connected to docking station/BYUI network)Â     Log into programsÂ Â     Outlook    Teams    After opening Teams, under "Sign In,"Â enter your BYUIÂ email, and then sign in using your BYUIÂ credentials    Office    Adobe    OneDrive    Browser    You will need to log in to a browser in order to get your bookmarks and settings    Check any additional programs or files that you use frequently.Â     What does Tech Support do?    At the date/time you've selected, we will remotely connect to your old computer and begin the file transfer process.    Tech Support will verify the migration has completed and come to exchange the old computer for new computer at a time arranged with the employee prior to/during the file transfer.Â     The employee may also indicate they are comfortable with the replacement taking place without them present, in which case Tech Support will deliver and setup the new computer, and recover the old computer.    Do I have to be there when the technician comes to replace my computer?    Am I able to work on my computer during the time that I.T. will be migrating my files?    It's encouraged that the computer not be used during the file migration.    However, if needed you can use the computer. Just ensure that any work or files you work on are not saved locally on the computer, but are saved to a different storage location like OneDrive.    What files are transferred?    Whatâ€™s included    Documents, pictures, most programs, printers, drivers, etcÂ     Whatâ€™s not included    Adobe programsÂ     Do I need to back up files?    Not required, but always recommendedÂ     Transfer vs backup (differences)Â Â     Transferring your files is essentially just copying your files from your old computer to your new computer. Both are stored locally on the computer.Â     Backing up your files to something like OneDrive stores the files in a cloud location where they are available even if you do not have access to your physical computer. Highly recommended as a way to ensure you donâ€™t lose files/data if something unexpected happens to your physical computer.Â Take a look atÂ Transferring Drive Files to OneDriveÂ for a walk throughÂ on backing up your files.    What if I forgot some files?    We hold onto computers for 2 weeks after they are replaced in case there are files missing.Â     Contact us if you find you are missing files/programs/etcÂ     What computer am I receiving?    You will be receiving a similar computer to the type you have currently. For example, if you currently have a Windows laptop, you will be receiving an updated Windows laptop, unless you have already made different arrangements with the I.T. department.Â     If youâ€™re not sure what new computer we have for you, please call the Tech Support Projects team at x9036.Â     What happens to my old computer?    We hold onto it for 2 weeks to ensure there are no files that you end up needing off of itÂ     We then wipe the machine and either reissue as a trickle computer or send it to Surplus SalesÂ Â     If interested in purchasing your old computer, make a note of the asset tag and keep in contact with Surplus Sales for when they receive that device so you can purchase it.Â     With hundreds of different computers being replaced each year, we are unable assist in tracking where your computer goes.Â     Can I keep my old computer after my new one is delivered to make sure everything is working?    The profile migration tool eliminates the majority of the situations where this would be needed.Â     If you feel this is still needed, approval will need to be given from the IT manager over the Tech Support Projects team. To request this permission, contact the projects team at technologysupportprojects@byui.edu or call x9036.Â     What if I am retiring at the end of this year?    Who do I call for help/assistance with my new computer?

Header: Removing BYUI Apple Devices from your Apple Account
Tags: apple mac retiree leaving-byui leaving-school return-computer leaving-faculty leaving-employee retiring-employee return-device return-technology computer-needs-wiped return-byui-computer remove-apple-device
Paragraphs: When employees leaveÂ BYUI, their devices need to be returned to IT or wiped for their replacements. If it is a windows device, the employee just need to leave the computer, power supply, and docking station with their department secretary who will take care of the device from there. If it is an apple device however, the device needs to be removed from the employee's apple account before it is left with their secretary.Â Below are the steps on how to remove the device. This applies for all Apple devicesÂ (Mac computers, tablets etc).    Removing the Apple DeviceÂ     1.Â Go to System Settings on the device you want to remove from your Apple account.    2.Â Click "Apple ID"Â (name at the top).    3.Â Scroll to the bottom and click "Sign Out."        4. If you would like to keep a copy of your data, click "Keep a Copy" in the window that pops up. If you don't want to keep a copy, uncheck all the boxes and click "Continue."        5.Â Once you are signed out of theÂ device, simplyÂ leave it with your department secretary. They will take care of the process of returning the device to IT (or getting it wiped for the next employee) from there.    Â     If for any reason the above process doesn't work, there is another way to remove the device, as outlined below. If this is being done from a phone/tablet instead of a computer, open the Find My app and skip to step 5.    1. Go to iCloud.com and click Sign In        2. Sign in using your personal Apple ID        3. You will be taken to your account page. In the section ofÂ apps, click and open "Find My"        4. It will ask you for your Apple ID password again        5. At the top, click "All Devices" then find the BYUIÂ device that you are returning        6. Click "Remove from Account"        7. Once the device is removed, simplyÂ leave it with your department secretary. They will take care of the process of returning the device to IT (or getting it wiped for the next employee) from there.

Tags: emails-wont-send cannot-send-email email-errors outlook-errors email-address-unrecognized no-connection-email outlook-email-error server-not-found errors-account
Paragraphs: This article contains information about common error messages in Microsoft Outlook, as well as tips to resolve the issue. Some errors and error messages you may encounter while using Microsoft Outlook include the following messages:    â€œCannot send this itemâ€ or â€œThe destination email address is unrecognizedâ€    This error message typically deals with how an outgoing email message has been formatted. Check theÂ To:Â field of the message first to ensure that the recipients address is correct.    This error can also occur when there is a problem within HTML-based email messages. Try changing the outbound messageâ€™s format to plain text or rich text should resolve this. VisitÂ Microsoft SupportÂ to find out how to change the message format.    Â     â€œNo connection could be made because the target machine actively refused itâ€,Â â€œThe server could not be foundâ€, orÂ â€œError 0x800CCC0Fâ€    First make sure that your computer still has an active network connection. To do this, click your computerâ€™s wireless icon to see which Wi-Fi network â€“ if any â€“ it is connected to.    If you have verified that you are connected to a network and are still experiencing issues with Outlook, make sure that there are no permissions issues interrupting your ability to send emails.    Occasionally, a blocked firewall port or over-aggressive antivirus software can cause this error.Â Try unblocking the firewall port or scaling back your antivirusâ€™s protections (at least temporarily).Â     If you have fixed any problems with your connectivity, firewall, or antivirus and are still having problems, delete and recreate your Outlook profile.    Â     Emails won't send    If you are having difficulty sending and/or receiving emails from your BYU-Idaho account, it is probably because a pop-up blocker on your computer is preventing this from happening. How you can disable the pop-up blocker varies depending on your Internet browser.    Google Chrome    1. Open Google Chrome.    2. Go to the Chrome menu and selectÂ Settings.        3. SelectÂ Show Advanced SettingsÂ at the bottom of the page.    4. UnderÂ Privacy, selectÂ Site Settings.        5. UnderÂ Pop-ups, select theÂ Blocked (recommended)Â toggle button so that it switches toÂ Allowed.        Safari    1. Open Safari.    2. SelectÂ SafariÂ from the menu at the top of the screen.    3. SelectÂ PreferencesÂ from theÂ SafariÂ menu.        4. TheÂ PreferencesÂ pane will open. SelectÂ Websites.        5. SelectÂ Pop-up WindowsÂ from the side menu.        6. From the list next toÂ When visiting other websites:, selectÂ Allow.        Internet Explorer

Header: Why Does Outlook Show 2 Different Emails?
Tags: outlook-login outlook-email-address byui-username username-email login-username BYUI-username-email different-email what-email-to-use email-to-login email Username two-emails why-two-emails 2-byui-emails what-is-the-difference-between-my-two-byui-emails two-school-emails school-issued-email
Paragraphs: The image below is an example of a user's account information with two different emails appearing in their Outlook profile.        This does not mean there are two separate emails to keep track of.    As shown in the image above, a user's email is sometimes displayed as a BYU-Idaho email (smithj347@byui.edu) and a username@byui.edu email (johnsmith@byui.edu). Both email addresses are attached to the same profile. An email sent toÂ smithj347@byui.eduÂ will go to the same inbox as one sent toÂ johnsmith@byui.edu.    Â     Which email should I use to log into a Microsoft application?    When users input their email address, Microsoft is only looking for the BYU-Idaho domain name of "@byui.edu". This lets Microsoft know that a BYU-Idaho user is wanting to log into their school account.        Once the user inputs the email, Microsoft will then open the BYU-Idaho login page, as shown below. Users will then input their username and password to log in. This will take the user to their individual profile.        Ultimately, it does not matter which email to use. Microsoft is mainly looking for the BYU-Idaho domain name. But if you are still not sure, here are troubleshooting options that may help:    1. Read the prompt, they should tell you which one to use. Look for phrases like "email address" or "username".    2. Always try your school email first if instructions are not clear. Your school email is theÂ abc18001@byui.eduÂ email, notÂ username@byui.edu.    3. Use yourÂ username@byui.eduÂ if your school email does not work.    4. Microsoft should take you to the BYU-Idaho login page if you are not already logged into your BYU-Idaho account.    5. Contact the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411 or through theÂ Live ChatÂ function if you continue to have problems.    Â     What is the difference between my BYU-Idaho username and my Outlook email?    A username and an email have very similar functions. Both take you to your personal profile.    This can be similar to a person having both a name and a nickname. Benjamin could easily also be called Ben or Bennie. Each of those names are used to refer to the same person.    This is similar to a user's account at BYU-Idaho. Microsoft Outlook simply has two different emails attached to the same profile. Again, having two emails is nothing to be concerned about.

Header: What Accesses Do I Have as an Alumni/Retiree from BYU-Idaho?
Tags: alumni access Office changes retiree alumni-benefits alumni-and-retiree-account-access access-account gsuite discounts status-update
Paragraphs: Here is a list of the most common questions on what you can and cannot do/get as an alumni or retiree from BYU-Idaho.    Office 365, Google Suite, and Zoom    Retirees will have access to their email forever.Â  However, retirees will only have access to other Office 365, G-Suite, and Zoom products until midnight of the last payrollÂ after they retire. After that point, they will be only be able to use Office if they'veÂ downloaded Microsoft Office (not 365) off the Hub.    Alumni are the same but the date is tied to their last grade posting.    Campus Computers    If you are an employee that will retire and yourÂ BYUI-Provided computer is set to be replaced that year, you can buy out the computer. If it is not set to be replaced that year, you must return it to the university.    Duo    Duo authentication will stop being required as soon as your employee/student's status changes into retiree/alumni.    University Store and University Downloads    After you are set to retirees and alumni, respectively, by HR, you will:    BYU-IÂ login    As a retiree or alumni, you also do not have access to myBYUI. However, there are other direct links you can access directly.    Here are helpful links to access information outside of myBYUI:    WiFi    Retirees can still access BYUIÂ Wi-Fi. They can use the main Wi-Fi and authenticate, however they only get the same accesses as the visitor network.    General differences between BYUIÂ and BYUIÂ Visitor:    CanvasÂ (I-Learn)    Alumni will have access to Canvas for as long as their account is active. So if they can log into the byuiÂ website, they can access their I-Learn. The direct link to I-Learn will be taken off their my.byui.edu dashboard as soon as they become an alumni, but they can still access it by going directly to the canvas website (https://byui.instructure.com/).

Put in your password.Â         3. Duo will now guide you through your Duo configuration.Â     4. Press next.Â         5. Press next.Â         6. On the selection screen, choose Duo Mobile.        7. Enter your phone number:Â         8. Verify your phone number.Â         9. A verification passcode will be sent to your phone.Â Â         10. Enter the verification code and press verify.Â Â         11. Download and install Duo Mobile. Once you installÂ  Duo Mobile, please open it and set your phone aside. Tags: Help-Desk on-campus personal-computer IT-help wifi-issues IT-help-desk software-troubleshooting help-with-a-personal-computer Hardware-questions in-person walk-up Computer-Help-Desk laptop-issues computer-help computer-support laptop-help
Paragraphs: What is the Help Desk?    The Help Desk provides in person, walk-up tech support to students and employees.Â It is staffed by technicians that are trained in basic hardware and software troubleshooting. It is a place studentsÂ can go if they need assistance with their personal devices and employees can go if they need assistance with their BYU-Idaho owned devices. (NOTE: Preferred location to assist employees is in their office.) An appointment is not needed for the Help Desk and assistance is available on a first-come, first-serve basis.Â     In order to receive help, students and employees need to bring their I-card with them to the Help Desk.    Where?        Hours

Tags: Zoom screen-sharing g-suite cisco-jabber request-to-work-from-home g-suite-login staff-questions video-conferencing admin-questions staff-faqs employee-faqs web-camera bandwidth-zoom storing-data monitors wfh personal-devices access-on-campus-systems
Paragraphs:
The resources and FAQs below will help you be successful as you work remotely. If you need more help, contact I.T. Service Desk atÂ (208) 496-1411Â or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble.    What tools exist for synchronous video conferencing and screen sharing?    Zoom is the official BYU-Idaho tool for video conferencing and screen sharing. BYU-Idaho is licensed for an unlimited number of Zoom meetings with up to 100 participants. Zoom is hosted via the internet. It should work well even when many people are using it. However, video chat can consume a high amount of bandwidth. We will be working with the vendor to monitor its load and capacity.    For zoom training, contact the I.T. Service Desk atÂ (208) 496-1411Â or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble. You can also contact theÂ Faculty Technology CenterÂ (FTC).    To learn how to add a Zoom meeting to any Outlook Calendar event, see theÂ Zoom for OutlookÂ article.    Â     How much bandwidth is required for Zoom?    Zoom has certain bandwidth requirements for audio and video calls. See the articleÂ System Requirements for PC, Mac, and Linux.    Â     What if I want to record a Zoom meeting and post is as a video?    Â     What computer should I use if Iâ€™m working from home?    The following questions should help you determine the right path forward:    Â     What data can I store or access on personal devices?    As an employee at BYU-Idaho, you can save files to Microsoft OneDrive, SharePoint, and Teams. It is recommended you save all your work to one of these products. However, saving personal files to these platforms is not supported by the I.T. department.    Saving files to Microsoft OneDrive, SharePoint, and/or Teams will automatically back up your files and allow you to share them with others. You should never store any sensitive BYU-Idaho data or files on your personal device.    See the following links for additional resources on how to use these products:    Â     Can I take monitors or other equipment home with me?    With your direct supervisorâ€™s approval, you can take your monitor, keyboard, mouse, and/or docking station home with your campus-issued laptop.    Â     What if I need a web camera?    If you require a web camera for working from home, you should work with your department to acquire one through approved purchasing methods (i.e. Amazon).    Â     How can I access on-campus systems (Jenzabar, iSeries, etc.) from home?    Certain applications are protected via campus firewalls and are only accessible on campus. A virtual private network (VPN) connection is required to access these from off campus. You can request VPN access by submitting a request atÂ VPN RequestÂ or by contactingÂ the I.T. Service Desk atÂ (208) 496-1411Â or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble.    The BYU-Idaho VPN is provided by redundant appliances with a theoretical capacity of 5000 users. Cisco has indicated they will temporarily provide additional free licenses as needed. While the system should scale to many more users, only those who need access to on-campus systems should request VPN access.    Â     What if Iâ€™m working from home and I need to use my desk phone?    You may forward your desk phone to a home phone or cell phone by pressing theÂ Forward allÂ button on your desk phone and entering the number you wish to forward calls to.    You may also use the Cisco Jabber application on your laptop or other device, like you would your desk phone. You can learn how to setup Cisco Jabber on your device by visiting theÂ Setting Up JabberÂ article.    Cisco Jabber can turn any computer or cell phone into a BYU-Idaho softphone and is available for up to 1500 concurrent users. To request this capability, contact the I.T. Service Desk atÂ (208) 496-1411Â or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble.    Â     What is G Suite?    G Suite is a set of online productivity tools provided by Google. You can use G Suite for Education as an additional option to collaborate and share documents and files, and connect with others at BYU-Idaho through messaging and video conferencing. As an employee or student, you have access to use Google apps including Drive, Docs, Sheets, Slides, Hangouts, and Forms. Keep in mind that the official applications used by BYU-Idaho for email and calendaring is Microsoft Outlook. Therefore, Googleâ€™s Gmail and Calendar are not available.

See the following link to learn more aboutÂ G Suite for Education.    Â     Where do I get help with G Suite?    To learn how to log in to G Suite with your BYU-Idaho account, visit theÂ G Suite Login ProcessÂ article for a step-by-step guide. If you are not able to log in, contact the I.T. Service Desk atÂ (208) 496-1411Â or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble for assistance.    G Suite products are not administered or supported by the Information Technology department. To find answers to questions about G Suite products and to get support, visitÂ G Suite for Education.    Â     Can BYU-Idaho expand network services to provide service off-campus?    BYU-Idaho is not equipped to provide internet or network services to students or employees off-campus. Faculty with unreliable connectivity at home may continue to operate from their campus offices as appropriate.

Tags: outlook 2fa Zoom duo gsuite google-g-suite contact-proctorio remote-faqs student-faqs remote-resources proctorio-faqs canvas-faqs
Paragraphs:
What is Zoom?    Zoom is BYU-Idahoâ€™s official video conferencing software. It can be used to hold class discussions and other meetings online. Zoom can also be used for the following:    You canÂ Download ZoomÂ on your computer or mobile device. The following resources will help you learn how to use the different features available:    Â     What is Duo Mobile Two-Factor Authentication?Â     Two-factor authentication (using Duo Mobile) is a security service to keep your personal account and information more secure. To learn more about 2-factor authentication, check out ourÂ Duo Help Guides    Â     HowÂ do I use Duo Mobile?    Set up your phone to receive a push notification from the Duo Mobile app to verify your identity when logging into your BYU-Idaho account while off campus. You can download this app for free on the Google Play Store and App Store.    See the additional resources below to help you setup Duo Mobile on your devices:    Â     What software is available to install on my computer?    Some software available for students to download, such as Microsoft Office, are available here:Â University Downloads.    Â     What do I do if I donâ€™t have access to software I need for my classes?    BYU-Idaho provides a Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) site that can be accessed via your personal computer. It allows students to access following software:    To access the VDI site, see the articleÂ Virtual Desktop Interface (VDI).    Â     What is OneDrive?    OneDrive is a cloud storage platform where you can save and share documents, presentations, videos, and other files. Each currently enrolled student is given 1 TB of free storage. OneDrive allows you to do the following:    To accessÂ OneDriveÂ through your browser, go to theÂ OneDriveÂ website. Check outÂ Accessing OneDriveÂ for how to access it from the desktop and mobile phone apps. Additional help can be found in the following articles:    Â     What is Outlook?    Outlook is BYU-Idaho's email provider for communicating with students, faculty, and staff. Email is the official communication channel for BYU-Idaho, and any important updates from the university will be sent through it. You can access Outlook through your Student Home page or through the desktop and mobile Outlook apps. Contact the IT Service Desk at 208-496-1411 for more help.Â     Â     What is Proctorio?    Proctorio is a remote proctoring system that monitors students while they are taking tests remotely. This allows you to take exams outside of the Testing Center.    To setup Proctorio on your computer, follow this tutorial:Â Setting Up Proctorio    Download the extension here:Â Proctorio Web Extension    Additional help can be found in the following article:Â Proctorio FAQs    Â     Where do I get help with Canvas?    In a remote course setting, faculty rely more on Canvas for course announcements, class discussions, assignments, quizzes, and posting grades. Access Canvas through I-Learn on your BYU-Idaho Student home page. Help with Canvas can be found on the following articles:    Â     What is G Suite?    G Suite is a set of online productivity tools provided by Google. You can use G Suite for Education as an additional option to collaborate, share documents and files, and connect with others at BYU-Idaho through messaging and video conferencing. As an employee or student, you have access to use Google apps including Drive, Docs, Sheets, Slides, Hangouts, and Forms. Keep in mind that the official application used by BYU-Idaho for email and calendaring is Microsoft Outlook. Therefore, Googleâ€™s Gmail and Calendar are not available.

Click the link to learn more abutÂ G Suite for Education.    Where do I get help with G Suite?    To learn how to log in to G Suite with your BYU-Idaho account, see the articleÂ G Suit Login ProcessÂ for a step by step guide. If you are not able to log in, call the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411 for assistance.    G Suite products are not administered or supported by the Information Technology department. To find answers to questions about G Suite products and to get support, seeÂ Product Support.

Tags: Log-In testing-center authenticate 2fa 2-factor-authentication duo duo-authentication-not-working duo-accounts duo-2fa how-often-to-authenticate set-up-2fa why-is-2fa-being-implemented on-campus-authentication account-authentication 30-days
Paragraphs: Why is 2-Factor Authentication being implemented?    We are adding this security measure to help keep your personal information as safe as possible. Even if someone else knows your username and password, they will not be able to get into your account unless they also have the device that you use to authenticate.â€¯    Check out the articleÂ Why Do We Need 2-Factor Authentication?Â for more information.    Â     How often will I need to authenticate?    Each authentication lasts forâ€¯30 days.â€¯That means that unless youâ€™ve recently cleared your history or cache, youâ€™re using a new Internet browser, or youâ€™re using Incognito mode, you will only have to go through the process every 30 days per device.Â Â     EXAMPLE:Â If you authenticated from your computer in Google Chrome, you would be authenticated for your computer and Google Chrome for 30 days. However, if you tried to access your BYU-Idaho account from the same computer later in the day, but used Safari instead of Google Chrome, you would need to authenticate again. You would then be authenticated for your home computer, for both Google Chrome and Safari, for 30 days. Within those 30 days, you would only need to authenticate again if you used a new device (e.g., a library computer) or another new browser.Â Â     Letâ€™s say that 15 days later, you cleared your cache after I-Learn maintenance. You would then need to authenticate again, and the 30-day period would restart.    Â     How do I set up 2-Factor Authentication?    For instructions on how to set up your Duo Mobile 2FA, visit our articleÂ Updated DUO Mobile Help Guide.    Â     When will 2-Factor Authentication be implemented for me?    Certain groups of students will receive authorization to begin setting up Duo Mobile accounts starting March 24, 2020. You will receive an email if you are included in one of these groups. A new group of students will be added every Tuesday until all students have been added to Duo Mobile. We hope to reach the completion of the project by June 2020. After that, every new student will join Duo Mobile upon registration at BYU-Idaho.    Â     Will I need to authenticate from the Testing Center?    No. We recognize that you will not be able to bring any authentication devices with you into the Testing Center, and so authentication in the Testing Center will not be required.Â Â     Â     What if I get an authentication notice when Iâ€™m not trying to log in to my account?    This means that someone is trying to get into your account. Deny the login request, and immediately change your BYU-Idaho password.    Â     Will I need to authenticate when using an on-campus network?    Yes. However, you will not need to authenticate when using a work computer that is â€œwired,â€ or plugged in, to an Internet connection. For example, if you were using a work computer during your shift you would not need to authenticate. However, when you left work, went to class, and started using your personal computer in class, you would need to authenticate if you had not authenticated for that computer and browser in the last 30 days.

Tags: Log-In Authentication 2fa 2-factor-authentication duo duo-mobile access-account duo-access why-do-we-need-2fa protect duo-2fa
Paragraphs: To understand why we need 2-Factor Authentication (2FA), we first need to understand what 2FA is helping to protect.Â     Why do we need 2FA?    The rationale behind this is simple but powerful: requiring 2FA for students to log in better protects student information. Unfortunately, we live in a world where more and more people can access your private information and use it for going places they shouldn't (like your bank account). Because your account information can be accessed from both on-campus and off, we protect it more than our other on-campus systems. With 2FA, we are able to add an extra step to that process which makes it easier for you to keep track of who, when, and even where someone logs in to your account. Since the authentication process is linked to your phone, you alone give permission for someone to log in to your account to be accessed. If you have lost your phone or got a new one, check out the articleÂ I Lost My Phone, or I Got a New Phone.    If you're worried authenticating is going to be a crazy complicated process, don't be. Simply log in to your BYU-Idaho account and follow the prompts to authenticate into your account. So don't freak out. By using 2FA, you are responsibly safeguarding your account.    Check out the video link below to learn more:

Paragraphs: Setting Up DUO Mobile for the First Time    If you are a student at BYU-Idaho, you will be required to enroll in 2-factor authentication (2FA). For more about 2FA,â€¯watch ourÂ Introduction: Why 2FA?Â video.Â     2. Sign in to your BYU-Idaho account.Â         3.Â After signing in you will be sent to a slideshow with information of why 2-Factor Authentication is important.    4. When you reach the page below click "Next"        5.Â Then on the next screen select DUO Mobile.Â         6. You will then enter your phone number.Â  You can also add tablet. If you do you will skip this step.        7.Â DUO Mobile will open and you will beÂ askedÂ to name the account.Â "BYU-Idaho" should be the default and is totally fine as a name.    8. From this point you should have access to useÂ DUO Pushes to you new phone number device.    9. To test if it has been set up correctly you can try to sign into you BYU-Idaho account.    Â     Managing Your Devices Enrolled with DUO Mobile    If you would like to add a new device, or delete an old one on your DUO Mobile account do the following.    2. Sign in to your BYU-Idaho account.Â         3.Â When you reach theÂ  DUO Screen below,Â Click "Need Help?".        4.Â After you have clicked the "Need help?" button, you will be brought this screen:        5. In the "Need help?" menu screen click "I need to manage devices".        7. After you authenticate, you will be brought to your devices page and it will lookÂ similar to this:        8. From here click on "Add a new device"Â  and select Duo Mobile        9. You will then enter your new phone number.Â  You can also add tablet. If you do you will skip this step.        10.Â DUO Mobile will open and you will beÂ askedÂ to name the account.Â "BYU-Idaho" should be the default and is totally fine as a name.    11. From this point you should have access to useÂ DUO Pushes to you new phone number device.    12.Â To test if it has been set up correctly you can try to sign into you BYU-Idaho account.    Â     Activating or Re-Activating DUO    Some times you may have deleted the DUO Mobile app and it is no longer sending you push notifications. One case can be is when you do that you will need to reactivate DUO. You will also have to do this same process when you get a new phone but keep your phone number.    1. Go to my.byui.edu to sign into your BYU-Idaho Account    2.Â When you reach theÂ  DUO Screen below,Â Click "Need Help?".        3.Â After you have clicked the "Need help?" button, you will be brought this screen:        4. In the "Need help?" menu screen click "Manage devices" under "I got a new phone"        6. After you authenticate, you will be brought to your devices page and it will lookÂ similar to this:        7.Â Click "I haveÂ a new phone" under the phone number that youÂ are still using.    8. YouÂ will be taken to the page below. Click "Get started."        9. YouÂ will be asked to download Duo Mobile. If youÂ do not yet have it, youÂ can install at this point and then click "Next."        10. To link the app to yourÂ account, youÂ can now click "Continue" if youÂ are doing this process on the device you have Duo Mobile installed on. If youÂ are using yourÂ computer or another device, youÂ can choose to "Get an activation link instead." Once youÂ click "continue" or the activation link, youÂ will be taken toÂ DuoÂ Mobile and youÂ will beÂ askedÂ to name the account.Â "BYU-Idaho" is default.        11. From this point youÂ should have access to useÂ DUO Pushes to that device.

Header: Sign In Process for New My.BYUI Online Students
Tags: Pathway mybyui help Account Login Church changed
Paragraphs: LoginÂ Information    In order to better serve these students, BYU-Idaho will support the same loginÂ method as before.Â Students that were once a part of "BYU-Pathway Worldwide" and are now served by BYU-Idaho Online will continue to loginÂ normally through the Pathway Worldwide loginÂ option and use their Church AccountÂ as seen in the example image below.    Steps to Login        If you still have questions please contact us. We are here to help!    Accessing Student Services    Many of our the students previously served by BYU-Pathway WorldwideÂ recently had their "service provider" changed from BYU-Pathway Worldwide toÂ BYU-Idaho Online. As a result, these students are now fully served by Brigham Young University-Idaho, which changes how students access important student services.    BYU-Idaho has conveniently centralized student services to a single student portal, known as "my.BYUI". All newly changed BYU-Idaho Online students can accessÂ student services by going toÂ my.byui.edu.    While for many, bookmarking the services below might work well and with minimal issues, But, we've made it easier for our students. For all of our resources, like course registrations, I-Learn, Email, etc., can be found by going to our student portal, myBYUIÂ (my.byui.edu). Feel free to bookmark the portal.Â     myBYUI    As an overview, here are some important student services that will be helpful for future reference. As a reminder, these services can also be found by simply visiting the my.BYUIÂ student portal.Â These are the highlight student services:Â     Support    BYU-Idaho is committed to each and every student's success. We have dedicated entire support teams to assisting you along the way. If you need help with anything, call us and don't hesitate. Here is a link to all of our support options, including a phone number to call. If you have questions about the change or need answers about registration or Financial Aid, click General Support below. If you need help logging in or have other technical issues, click Technical Support below.

Currently, all students will need to click their student type when they see the "log in screen"Â on I-Plan.Â     A tip we found helpful for newly converted online students is to loginÂ through the yellow PathwayConnectÂ loginÂ button. This button is meant to work for anyone using their Church Account as their loginÂ information.Â     Steps to Follow    So if you loginÂ and somehow you can't get into I-Plan, you're seeing an error message, or you "don't have access," please try:    Here are some screen steps:        Support    BYU-Idaho is committed to each and every student's success. Paragraphs: Changing Your Name in I-Learn & Canvas    "Preferred" Name    Canvas will put whatever is in the preferred name section as your name, and then adds on your last name to that, often causing the double last name to appear.Â If you have your first and last name or middle name in the "Preferred" field, change it to just your first name.    1.Â LoginÂ to my.byui.edu and click your profile pictureÂ in the top right then "View Profile"        2. Click "Edit Personal Information"        3. Next to Preferred First Name click "EDIT"        4. EnterÂ ONLYÂ your First Name and click "Update"        5.Â Check Canvas again in the next business day, as it often takes a few hours for the field to refresh.Â     Request a Name Change    1.Â LoginÂ to my.byui.edu and click your profile pictureÂ in the top right then "View Profile"        2. Click "Edit Personal Information"        3. ClickÂ "Change" next to your name.        4. Select the reason for the name change        5.Â Input name changes        6. Upload a picture ofÂ your Social Security Card        7. Confirm the name change    8.Â Check Canvas again in the next business day, as it often takes a few hours for the field to refresh.

Tags: video discussionboard canvas canvas-discussion-board canvas-discussion-board-video-issues upload-error video-file dicussion-post
Paragraphs: Issues with videos on theÂ discussion board can be separated into 3 different underlying issues.    1.Â The video file isÂ too large.    Upload the video directly to your My MediaÂ page. You may then embed the video into your discussion board as you would a normal zoom recording.            2.Â TheÂ video may be in the wrong format.    Canvas likes to have videos in theÂ MP4 Format. If this is the issue, upload the video to My MediaÂ and then embed it into the discussion board.    3.Â You may have aÂ Slow Internet Connection.    If you google Internet Speed Test and click the "run test" button it will test the speed of the Internet.Â If a slow Internet connection is anÂ issue, try to find a place with a better Internet connection.

Paragraphs: This document will guide you through setting up Duo for your Pathway account at BYU-Idaho.Â     1. Go to secure.byui.edu and click on the BYU-Pathway Worldwide Login.Â         2. Sign in with your church account, which should be the account you used to apply for school and register for classes.Â Â Â     2a. Put in your church username.Â         2b. Put in your password.Â         3. Duo will now guide you through your Duo configuration.Â     4. Press next.Â         5. Press next.Â         6. On the selection screen, choose Duo Mobile.        7. Enter your phone number:Â         8. Verify your phone number.Â         9. A verification passcode will be sent to your phone.Â Â         10. Enter the verification code and press verify.Â Â         11. Download and install Duo Mobile. Once you installÂ  Duo Mobile, please open it and set your phone aside. Now on your computerâ€™s browser, click next.Â         12. A QR code like the one below will be on your browserâ€™s screen. In the Duo Mobile App, click add, then use the QR code. Scan the QR code. Alternatively, use the get activation link to add the code manually.Â Â         13. The QR code will change to a green checkmark verifying youâ€™ve successfully added your account.Â Â         14. Press continue.Â         15. Click skip.Â         16. Click Log in with DuoÂ         17. Log in using the option that best suits your needs.Â     For most users, Duo Push will be the most secure and convenient option and is recommended by BYU-Idaho.Â Â     If your network connection is unreliable, we recommend Duo Mobile passcode as it does not require network or cell towers.Â Â     For devices that cannot download the Duo Mobile app the text, phone, and bypass codes options are provided. Bypass codes may be needed if phone systems are intermittent in your area. If you need help, please contact the IT Service desk through the login help webpage at https://www.byui.edu/information-technology/.Â     For more information on using the different Login options, see the Duo Universal Prompt Login Options section in the Duo setup guide.Â         18. Your Duo setup is complete if you see the successful login screen.

Tags: notification duo staff-questions staff-faq faculty-faq faculty-questions why-2fa why-duo-mobile 30-day-authentication duo-token second-authentication-device authentication-token classroom-or-office
Paragraphs: Have questions about 2-Factor Authentication (2FA)? Read the Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) below.    Why is 2FA being implemented?    We are adding this security measure to help keep your personal information as safe as possible. Even if someone else knows your username and password, they will not be able to get into your account unless they also have the device that you use to authenticate. Â     Check out the articleÂ Why Do We Need 2-Factor Authentication?Â for more information.    Â     How often will I need to authenticate?    Each authentication lasts for about 14 days if you select 'Yes this is my device'. That means that unless youâ€™ve recently cleared your history or cache, youâ€™re using a new Internet browser, or youâ€™re using Incognito mode, you will only have to go through the process every 14 days per device.    Letâ€™s say that 10 days later, you cleared your history. You would then need to authenticate again, and the 14-day period would restart.    Â     How do I set up 2FA?    To see the step-by-step tutorial on how to set up Duo Mobile 2FA, visit our articleÂ How to Set Up 2-Factor Authentication with Duo Mobile.    Â     What methods are available for me to authenticate with if I donâ€™t have a mobile phone as my second authentication device?    Authentication Methods include:    Note: SMS and phone call passcodes will no longer be available    If a phone was left at home or lost, a call to the help desk can give you a temporary bypass code for a few days until the phone is recovered.Â For users that need exceptions, we will have some alternate MFA options available such as a Yubi key or Duo Hardware token, depending on the situation. These users should work with their supervisor for approval.Â     If you do not have a smartphone,Â we strongly recommend using the push notification option to a device capable of downloading the Duo Mobile app. Not only is this option quicker, easier, and can be used offline, it also doesn't cost any money to the school for messaging and data rates.Â     Â     Could I use a security key with DUO?    You can get an authentication token by contacting the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411 or through theÂ ChatÂ bubble. A token will cost a one-time fee of $30 but will supply passcodes on an as-needed basis for as long as 2FA is utilized at BYU-Idaho (in other words, for the foreseeable future). You can also purchase a security key. See ourÂ Security Keys and DUOÂ tech guide for more information.Â     Â     Will I need to authenticate from my classroom or office?    Yes.Â By request of the CES SOC, BYU-Idaho will be changing the security model for all on-campus devices. This new model will require Multi-FactorÂ Authentication (MFA) for all resources that use SSO (Canvas, BYUI Portal, Workday, etc...). This new model will be similar to the experience of accessing BYU-Idaho SSO authenticated resources off campus.Â The use of DuoÂ will be required.Â     Â     What if I get an authentication notice when Iâ€™m not trying to log in to my account?    This means that someone is trying to get into your account. Deny the login request, and immediately change your BYU-Idaho password.

Certain groups of students will receive authorization to begin setting up Duo Mobile accounts starting March 24, 2020. You will receive an email if you are included in one of these groups. A new group of students will be added every Tuesday until all students have been added to Duo Mobile. We hope to reach the completion of the project by June 2020. After that, every new student will join Duo Mobile upon registration at BYU-Idaho.    Â     Will I need to authenticate from the Testing Center?    No. We recognize that you will not be able to bring any authentication devices with you into the Testing Center, and so authentication in the Testing Center will not be required.Â Â     Â     What if I get an authentication notice when Iâ€™m not trying to log in to my account?    This means that someone is trying to get into your account. Deny the login request, and immediately change your BYU-Idaho password.    Â     Will I need to authenticate when using an on-campus network?    Yes. However, you will not need to authenticate when using a work computer that is â€œwired,â€ or plugged in, to an Internet connection. For example, if you were using a work computer during your shift you would not need to authenticate. However, when you left work, went to class, and started using your personal computer in class, you would need to authenticate if you had not authenticated for that computer and browser in the last 30 days.

Tags: Log-In Authentication 2fa 2-factor-authentication duo duo-mobile access-account duo-access why-do-we-need-2fa protect duo-2fa
Paragraphs: To understand why we need 2-Factor Authentication (2FA), we first need to understand what 2FA is helping to protect.Â     Why do we need 2FA?    The rationale behind this is simple but powerful: requiring 2FA for students to log in better protects student information. Unfortunately, we live in a world where more and more people can access your private information and use it for going places they shouldn't (like your bank account). Because your account information can be accessed from both on-campus and off, we protect it more than our other on-campus systems. With 2FA, we are able to add an extra step to that process which makes it easier for you to keep track of who, when, and even where someone logs in to your account. Since the authentication process is linked to your phone, you alone give permission for someone to log in to your account to be accessed. If you have lost your phone or got a new one, check out the articleÂ I Lost My Phone, or I Got a New Phone.    If you're worried authenticating is going to be a crazy complicated process, don't be. Simply log in to your BYU-Idaho account and follow the prompts to authenticate into your account. So don't freak out. By using 2FA, you are responsibly safeguarding your account.    Check out the video link below to learn more:

Tags: duo duo-set-up duo-help duo-verification duo-activation cant-have-the-duo-mobile-app no-way-to-get-past-duo cant-get-past-duo access-to-duo duo-access 2fa-duo duo-incompatible cant-install-duo passkey duo-passkey security-key byui-duo-security-key
Paragraphs:
What is a Passkey?    With help from Apple and Android, you can now add a Passkey to your Duo account in order to authenticate. Passkeys are similar to Security keys (which you can learn more about inÂ this Help Guide) but the key is stored on your phone instead of an external device. Duo will label these as Passkey instead of Security Keys.Â     You can use a passkey to authenticate with Duo even when youÂ are offline, as long as youÂ have yourÂ phone. It is also a great substitute if youÂ can't get the Duo app or texts or phone calls. However, the Passkey feature is only available on newer devices. On iPhone, you must have a phone with iOS 16 or later,Â and Android 9 or later is required for Android Phones.

For more information, reference this article from Duo:Â https://duo.com/blog/what-are-passkeys    How to add a Passkey    1. Go to the duo authentication page and click "Other Options"        2. From the list of other options, select "Mangage Devices"        3. Verify your identity using your preferred method        4. Now that you are on the "Manage Devices" page, click "Add a Device"        5. Choose the "Security Key" option        6. Click "Continue"        7. Click "OK"        8. ClickÂ "Cancel"        9. Select "Use a phone or tablet"        10. A QR code will come up for you to scan with your phone's camera. From there, follow the instructions on your phone to finish adding it as a passkey.    11. When the security key has been successfully added, you will get the following message. Click "Continue" to be taken back to the devices page.        12. It should show up in your devices page as shown below        13. You can now go back to the login page and use your passkey to authenticate. It will pull up a QR code for you to scan with your phone. Scan the QR code to authenticate and you will be logged in.

Header: Duo Setup for New Pathway Worldwide Users
Tags: Pathway duo pathway-duo 2fa-duo byu-pathway byu-pathway-worldwide set-up-duo set-up-duo-pathway
Paragraphs: This document will guide you through setting up Duo for your Pathway account at BYU-Idaho.Â     1. Go to secure.byui.edu and click on the BYU-Pathway Worldwide Login.Â         2. Sign in with your church account, which should be the account you used to apply for school and register for classes.Â Â Â     2a. Put in your church username.Â         2b. Put in your password.Â         3. Duo will now guide you through your Duo configuration.Â     4. Press next.Â         5. Press next.Â         6. On the selection screen, choose Duo Mobile.        7. Enter your phone number:Â         8. Verify your phone number.Â         9. A verification passcode will be sent to your phone.Â Â         10. Enter the verification code and press verify.Â Â         11. Download and install Duo Mobile. Once you installÂ  Duo Mobile, please open it and set your phone aside. Now on your computerâ€™s browser, click next.Â         12. A QR code like the one below will be on your browserâ€™s screen. In the Duo Mobile App, click add, then use the QR code. Scan the QR code. Alternatively, use the get activation link to add the code manually.Â Â         13. The QR code will change to a green checkmark verifying youâ€™ve successfully added your account.Â Â         14. Press continue.Â         15. Click skip.Â         16. Click Log in with DuoÂ         17. Log in using the option that best suits your needs.Â     For most users, Duo Push will be the most secure and convenient option and is recommended by BYU-Idaho.Â Â     If your network connection is unreliable, we recommend Duo Mobile passcode as it does not require network or cell towers.Â Â     For devices that cannot download the Duo Mobile app the text, phone, and bypass codes options are provided. Bypass codes may be needed if phone systems are intermittent in your area. If you need help, please contact the IT Service desk through the login help webpage at https://www.byui.edu/information-technology/.Â     For more information on using the different Login options, see the Duo Universal Prompt Login Options section in the Duo setup guide.Â         18. Your Duo setup is complete if you see the successful login screen.

Paragraphs: Setting Up DUO Mobile for the First Time    If you are a student at BYU-Idaho, you will be required to enroll in 2-factor authentication (2FA). For more about 2FA,â€¯watch ourÂ Introduction: Why 2FA?Â video.Â     2. Sign in to your BYU-Idaho account.Â         3.Â After signing in you will be sent to a slideshow with information of why 2-Factor Authentication is important.    4. When you reach the page below click "Next"        5.Â Then on the next screen select DUO Mobile.Â         6. You will then enter your phone number.Â  You can also add tablet. If you do you will skip this step.        7.Â DUO Mobile will open and you will beÂ askedÂ to name the account.Â "BYU-Idaho" should be the default and is totally fine as a name.    8. From this point you should have access to useÂ DUO Pushes to you new phone number device.    9. To test if it has been set up correctly you can try to sign into you BYU-Idaho account.    Â     Managing Your Devices Enrolled with DUO Mobile    If you would like to add a new device, or delete an old one on your DUO Mobile account do the following.    2. Sign in to your BYU-Idaho account.Â         3.Â When you reach theÂ  DUO Screen below,Â Click "Need Help?".        4.Â After you have clicked the "Need help?" button, you will be brought this screen:        5. In the "Need help?" menu screen click "I need to manage devices".        7. After you authenticate, you will be brought to your devices page and it will lookÂ similar to this:        8. From here click on "Add a new device"Â  and select Duo Mobile        9. You will then enter your new phone number.Â  You can also add tablet. If you do you will skip this step.        10.Â DUO Mobile will open and you will beÂ askedÂ to name the account.Â "BYU-Idaho" should be the default and is totally fine as a name.    11. From this point you should have access to useÂ DUO Pushes to you new phone number device.    12.Â To test if it has been set up correctly you can try to sign into you BYU-Idaho account.    Â     Activating or Re-Activating DUO    Some times you may have deleted the DUO Mobile app and it is no longer sending you push notifications. One case can be is when you do that you will need to reactivate DUO. You will also have to do this same process when you get a new phone but keep your phone number.    1. Go to my.byui.edu to sign into your BYU-Idaho Account    2.Â When you reach theÂ  DUO Screen below,Â Click "Need Help?".        3.Â After you have clicked the "Need help?" button, you will be brought this screen:        4. In the "Need help?" menu screen click "Manage devices" under "I got a new phone"        6. After you authenticate, you will be brought to your devices page and it will lookÂ similar to this:        7.Â Click "I haveÂ a new phone" under the phone number that youÂ are still using.    8. YouÂ will be taken to the page below. Click "Get started."        9. YouÂ will be asked to download Duo Mobile. If youÂ do not yet have it, youÂ can install at this point and then click "Next."        10. To link the app to yourÂ account, youÂ can now click "Continue" if youÂ are doing this process on the device you have Duo Mobile installed on. If youÂ are using yourÂ computer or another device, youÂ can choose to "Get an activation link instead." Once youÂ click "continue" or the activation link, youÂ will be taken toÂ DuoÂ Mobile and youÂ will beÂ askedÂ to name the account.Â "BYU-Idaho" is default.        11. From this point youÂ should have access to useÂ DUO Pushes to that device.

Tags: security keys duo yubico yubikey enrolling security-key-duo feitian how-to-add-a-security-key
Paragraphs: Overview    BYU-Idaho has enabled and supports the use of security keys, also known as passkeys or hardware tokens, for use with DUO/2FA. But, these devices must meet theÂ WebAuthn/FIDO2 security protocol (please see DUO'sÂ security requirements documentation for more information). Devices that do not meet this protocol are not supported and cannot be used with DUO.    These security keys are a safe, reliable optionÂ for 2-factor authentication. However, we strongly advise users to be familiar with the setup, configuration, and daily operation ofÂ these devices, before making the decision to purchase them. Since there are a wide variety of different brands and models, we cannot make specific device or brand recommendations. Due to the wide variety of brands, models, and specificationsÂ BYU-I support personnelÂ cannot troubleshoot or resolve issues arising while using or operating these devices. We highly recommend contacting the manufacturer since they can offer the specific support required for the correct make and model.Â     Requirements    The following criteria must be met to use security keys with a BYU-I DUO account:    For more requirements, please visitÂ DUO'sÂ security requirements documentation.Â     What are security keys?    To put it simply, a security key is a physical device that can be used as another form of 2-factor authentication. Security keys are a promising trend in cyber security which seeks to add more security and resistance to phishing attacks. And for a tech-savvy user, security keys can also add a layer of convenience, since it offers the speed of taping on a USB device already plugged into your computer. By design, security keys are physical devices that are plugged into a USB port on your computer. The small USBÂ device then acts as your 2nd form of authentication with just a tap on the device when prompted by DUO. In a lot of cases, this might be a better solution for users wishing to have fewer required apps on their smartphones and/or for international users that may not have access to a smartphone. In most cases, users should opt for free, more user-friendly options, such as using DUO mobile push notifications.    DUOÂ makes security keys an option for organizations and BYU-Idaho has elected to allow users to add security keys to their accounts.Â As with allÂ authentication services, such as usernamesÂ and passwords, these security keys should be kept safe, protected, and out of reach of those with unauthorized access. Please keep these devices in a safe location. If you lose your security key, remove it from your DUO account as soon as possible, so the security of your BYUI account remains uncompromised.    Please note: if you are someone easily frustrated by technology, security keys may not be a good option.Â Security keys are not always a cheap option; prices can range from $19 to $100+. Replacing lost security keys requires purchasing a new key, removing the old device from your DUO account, and adding the replacement. If you DO choose to use a security key, we highly recommend buying at least two (with one as a backup) and having another authentication method enabled on your account (such as DUO Mobile, SMS, etc.). Doing so will prevent you from inadvertently being locked out of your account in the unfortunate situation of a lost key.Â     Here are just a few examples of available security keys:Â     How to configure with DUO    You must have the device in hand and ready to be plugged into your computer. Adding the security key is quick and easy. Follow these steps:    Important: security keys can only be added by the user. Due to the inherent nature of these devices, namely all security keys are physical hardware devices and must be plugged into the user's device to be configured, the IT Service Desk is limited in how they can help. If you chose to use such a device, please note that you assume all responsibilityÂ and the required self-service.    For information on how to add and use security keys on your DUO account, please visit the DUO help guide DUO Universal Prompt guide for step-by-step instructions.    How to use security keys    Using a security key for DUO is fairly simple. Once you've configured your account to use the security key(s), you'll see "Security key" as an option on your screen whenever you're prompted to use Duo. When you select "Security key" simply follow the on-screen promptsâ€”it's easy. If you find yourself still having issues though, feel free to check out Duo's articles at guide.duo.com    Support Information

Header: I Didnâ€™t Get a Push Notification
Tags: duo two-factor-authentication-2fa duo-ios duo-2fa duo-push-notifications push-notification-errors 2fa-notifications troubleshooting-duo internet-connectioin duo-android
Paragraphs: Here is a list of options to try if you do not receive a push notification after enrolling in yourÂ phone number.    iPhone    Enable notifications for the Duo Mobile app    When you first downloadâ€¯the app, a requestâ€¯appearsâ€¯asking you if you would like to allow Duo Mobile to send you notifications.â€¯You may have selected "Don'tâ€¯Allow" when this notification appeared, but you will have to allow notifications for the Duo Mobile app for it to work properly.â€¯    Toâ€¯allowâ€¯notifications for Duo Mobile:â€¯â€¯Â     1. Go toÂ Settings.â€¯Â         2. Scroll down and selectÂ Duo Mobile.â€¯Â         3. SelectÂ Notifications.â€¯â€¯Â         4. Allow notifications by tapping on the white toggle button.â€¯â€¯        Refreshing the Duo Mobile app    If you are allowing notifications for the Duo Mobile app but are still not receiving notifications, goâ€¯toâ€¯the Duo app andâ€¯pull down the screen. This will refresh your account and load all missing notifications. Approve the authentication request,â€¯and you are done.        Checking your internet connection    To use the Duo Mobile app, you will need a strongâ€¯Internetâ€¯connection. Try turning the Wi-Fi on and off to reset a wireless network that is having issues connecting to your device. If you have cellular data, turn off your Wi-Fiâ€¯and use data insteadâ€¯in order to get a betterâ€¯Internet connection.    Â     Android    This article is meant to help you troubleshoot problems with push notifications on an Androidâ€¯device.â€¯    Refreshing theâ€¯Duo Mobile app    Goâ€¯to the Duo Mobile appâ€¯andâ€¯pull down the screen. This will refresh your account and load all missing notifications.â€¯Find the notification you were trying to get and approve the authentication request.    Updating Google Play    If you are still not getting push notifications, you might need to check that Google Playâ€¯is updated.â€¯If Google Play is out-of-date, update it.    Clearing the Duo Mobile app cache    You can also clear the Duo Mobile app cacheâ€¯to try and free up any trapped notifications. To clear the Duo Mobile app cache:â€¯    1. Go toÂ Settings.â€¯    2. SelectÂ AppsÂ and scroll down to selectÂ Duo Mobile.â€¯Â         3. TapÂ Clear Cache.â€¯â€¯Â         Checking your Internet connection    If none ofâ€¯the previous stepsâ€¯work, check that you are using a strongâ€¯Internet connection. Try turning the Wi-Fi onâ€¯and off to reset theâ€¯wireless network. If you have cellular data, turn off your Wi-Fiâ€¯and use data instead in order to get a betterâ€¯Internet connection.

Header: I Didnâ€™t Get an SMS Text or a Phone Call
Tags: duo-authentication-not-working duo-errors duo-authentication how-to-set-up-2fa-byui passcodes did-not-receive-text no-phone-call duo-call duo-text no-code-on-duo cellular-connection
Paragraphs: This article provides possible causes and solutions if you do not receive a code when you choose to authenticate via text message.â€¯Â     An SMSÂ Text or Phone Call    Problems receiving text passcodesÂ or authentication verification from Duo could be due to one of the following factors:â€¯    Weak cellular connection    Make sure that your cell phone connection is strong. If your cellular connection is weak, find a place where you haveâ€¯a better connection. If you are usingâ€¯a smart phone, youâ€¯mayâ€¯be able to improveâ€¯your cellular data connectionâ€¯by turningÂ Airplane ModeÂ on and off. This will reset the connection and then you will be able to receive the authentication text.â€¯â€¯Â     Check your phone connection    If you have chosen a mobile phone,â€¯then make sure that the phone network connection is strong. You need to have connection in order to receive the call. If you areâ€¯usingâ€¯a landline, make sure that your phone is connected as well.â€¯â€¯Â     Problem with your device    If your phone connection is good, but youâ€¯still donâ€™t receive a text, there might be a problem with your device.

Paragraphs: If you lose your phone    For more information about how you can update your Duo Mobile Settings on your own, see the article on DUO Mobile Help Guide    If you get a new phone or a new phone number    If you get a new phone and were not able to update your Duo account, and/or you got a new phone number, contact the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411 or theirÂ Live ChatÂ to have your account reinstated.    If you got a new phone but still have the same phone number, see the article onÂ DUO Mobile Help GuideÂ to can connect your new phone to your Duo account.    Â     If you find your phone    If you find your phone, call the I.T. Service Desk again to have your account reinstated.

Header: I Need a Bypass Code for DUO Mobile
Tags: duo bypass-code duo-bypass Duo-bypass-code bypass-codes bypass-duo-for-missionaries bypass i-need-a-bypass-code how-to-get-a-bypass-code what-is-a-bypass-code
Paragraphs: What is a Bypass Code for DUO Mobile?    A bypass code is an authenticationÂ method reserved for people who cannot used DUOÂ Mobile in other traditional ways. i.eÂ  DUO Push Notification, a text message, phone call, etc.Â  It is a 9-digit-code that can be usedÂ to help be able to changeÂ Duo settings or get into your BYU-Idaho account.Â     Â     How Do I Get a Bypass Code?    In order to get a a bypass code you will need to talk to a member of the IT Service Desk. They will assess your situation and determine if you qualify for a Bypass code.    Depending on you circumstances, the bypass code you receiveÂ may have a limited amount of uses or only be used once. The IT Service Desk employee will help inform you about these conditions when you receive a Bypass code.Â     You may also be asked to verify you identity before the IT Service Desk employee can give you a bypass code. This is to ensure the safety of you account and stop any identity theft.

Header: Why Am I Locked Out of Duo?
Tags: account-locked duo duo-mobile account-has-been-locked 2fa-duo duo-mobile-locked excessive-authentication-failures your-account-has-been-locked
Paragraphs: Excessive Authentication Failures    If you are locked out of yourÂ DuoÂ account due to the error message: "Your account has been locked out due to excessive authenticationÂ failures. Please contact your administrator." (Shown below)        Please wait 60 minutes before contacting the IT Service Desk. Duo Mobile will put a temporary lock on your account due to what it assumes is suspicious account behavior. But after the 60-minute time period, your account should be unlocked. If your Duo account is locked a second time after the 60 minute timer, you may need to re-add your device, at this pointÂ feel free to contact the IT Service Desk.

Tags: ios Privacy restrictions parking-restrictions duo Catalina macOS duo-ios ios-devices-and-duo duo-access duo-restrictions content-restrictions screen-time disabling-restrictions
Paragraphs: Disabling Content Restrictions    iOS 12 or newer    1. Navigate toÂ SettingsÂ >Â Screen TimeÂ >Â Content & Privacy RestrictionsÂ >Â Content RestrictionsÂ >Â Web Content    2. UncheckÂ Limit Adult WebsitesÂ to completely disable content restrictions.    - If you do not want to fully disable content restrictions, you can allowÂ duosecurity.comÂ within the Content Restrictions page on the iOS device. This will allow the Duo Prompt to display even if content restrictions are enabled.    iOS 11 or older    1. Go toÂ SettingsÂ >Â GeneralÂ >Â RestrictionsÂ >Â Websites    2. UncheckÂ Limit Adult ContentÂ to completely disable content restrictions.    macOS 10.15 (Catalina) or higher    1. OpenÂ System Preferences    2. Navigate toÂ Screen TimeÂ >Â Preferences > Content & Privacy    3. Set any Web Content restrictions toÂ Unrestricted access    - If you do not want to fully disable content restrictions, you can allowÂ duosecurity.comÂ within the Content Restrictions page on the iOS device or to the Allowed Websites Only list on macOS. This will allow the Duo Prompt to display even if content restrictions are enabled.

Tags: phone-terms define-barge define-call define-call-waiting define-conference-call define-cradle define-handoff define-handover define-hard-keys define-hook define-line define-soft-keys
Paragraphs: Barge:Â The ability to add yourself to already established calls taking place between other people.Â     Call:Â Using a telephone to reach another in order to have a conversation.Â     Call Waiting:Â Your phoneâ€™s ability to alert you of incoming calls while you are already on the phone with another party. When call waiting is utilized, an incoming call will be indicated by a beeping sound while the partyâ€™s name and number appear on the phone screen.Â     Conference Call:Â Phone calls which take place between several separate entities, each in a separate location and utilizing a separate phone.Â     Cradle:Â The part of the phoneâ€™s external hardware where the phone rests when not in use.Â     Handoff:Â When one party transfers a phone call and all the concerns and responsibilities thereof, to a different party.Â     Handover:Â Synonymous with â€œhandoff.â€Â     Hard keys:Â Buttons with actions that are consistent; the actions they perform when pressed do not change.Â     Hook:Â An electronic toggle that indicates when your phone is hung up. It can be found near the top of your phone cradle. When the phone is absent from its cradle, the phone is said to be â€œoff the hook.â€ A phone being â€œoff the hookâ€ is usually indicated by a fast-paced beeping sound when aÂ third-party attemptÂ to call the phone in question.Â     Line:Â AÂ telephone connection.Â     Soft keys:Â Buttons that perform different actions when pressed, depending on the context. On your Cisco phone, the buttons of your soft keys will have their actions indicated by the touchscreen adjacent to the buttons.

Tags: cisco-phone start-cisco-phone maintain-cisco-phone getting-a-new-office-phone new-phone-request How-to-get-a-cisco-phone
Paragraphs: Who do I contact for a phone?    To get set up with a Cisco phone at BYU-Idaho, call the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411. Have your name, location, and an account number ready prior to calling.    Â     What is the ticket type? Paragraphs: Conference Calls    Beginning a conference call    1. Call one of the members of the pending conference call, just as you normally would.Â     2. While on the phone with one of the members of the pending conference call, pressÂ theÂ ConferenceÂ button.            3. Punch in the phone number of the contact you wish to add to the call and then pressÂ Call.    Note:Â In this example, 705 is used as the contact number.        4. Press theÂ ConferenceÂ button again.    You should now have successfully added the contact to the existing call.            6. Repeat these steps as many times as you need to in order to add everyone to the call.    Removing individual members from a conference call    Â     Managing multiple phone lines    Follow the instructions below to manage multiple active calls.Â When you are on an active call, you know that a call is waiting when you hear a single beep and see the line button flash.    Switching between multiple calls    Answering a call while maintaining another call    If you are in the middle of a call when another call comes through that you wish to answer immediately, tell the person on the phone they will be placed on hold, then press theÂ lineÂ button. The current phone call will then be placed on hold in favor of the incoming call.Â     Sending calls straight to voicemail    If you are in the middle of a phone call when another phone call interrupts, tapÂ iDivertÂ to send the new call straight to voicemail.Â     Â     Managing your voicemail    Setting up your voicemail    How do I know if I have new messages?    When checking to see whether you have new messages, look for a steady red light on your headset. You may also see a flashing envelope icon with the captionÂ Message WaitingÂ flashing on your screen. Additionally, waiting messages may be indicated by a stutter tone from your handset, headset, or speakerphone when you place a call.    Accessing your voicemail    Deleting a voicemail from your phone    Speed dialing    You can configure a speed dial button from your phone using the following procedure:
