Tags: blocked blocked-emails quarantined unblock-emails quarantined-emails quarantine-settings
Paragraphs: We've partnered with Microsoft Office 365's Exchange Online Protection (EOP) to automatically quarantine highly-suspicious messages at the server level before they even reach yourâ€¯Inboxâ€¯orâ€¯Junk E-mailâ€¯folder.Â You will occasionally receive a message from quarantine@messaging.microsoft.com indicating that you have X (number) of new spam-quarantined messages.Â (see the instructions below to review messages even if you don't receive this email)    You will be given the following three options for each email:    Release to Inbox    This sends the message to your regular inbox. This is usually used to review the message in more detail to determine whether it's something that you want to continue to allow us to quarantine, whether you can safely unsubscribe from the message, or whether you want to report to us that it is not - in fact - junk.    Report as Not Junk    This sends a copy of the message to the support team for analysis. If you're certain that the message should not have been quarantined - based on your review of theâ€¯Senderâ€¯andâ€¯Subjectâ€¯from the report and/or from having used the "Release to Inbox"â€¯link to review it in more detail - this is how you'd let us know that you don't want these messages quarantined in the future.    "This client requires a certificate"    If you're on a Mac usingâ€¯Safariâ€¯as your default browser, you may need to make a change to a certificate in order to avoid the "This client requires a certificate" message. â€¯Here's aÂ Microsoft Support articleÂ explaining how to do that.    Â     Reviewing Quarantined Emails    If you are having trouble using the quarantine portal on Safari, followÂ these steps.Â         Â     Editing Quarantine Settings        2. Â  Â Click the "+ Add" under the respective field (if you scroll up you should see a similar heading regarding "Blocked senders and domains" if that is what you would like to do).

Paragraphs: There are lots of functions the Outlook Desktop can do. Select the section you want to learn more about.    For instructions on how to combine school and personal email see the articleÂ Setting Up Email on a Mobile Device.    Texting from Email    If you need to get a message to someone who might not have access to their email, you can text them from your own email.Â     1. OpenÂ Outlook.Â     2. ClickÂ NewÂ EmailÂ orÂ New MessageÂ to compose a new draft.        3. Enter the recipientâ€™s ten-digit cell phone number in theÂ To:Â field, followed by theÂ @Â symbol.    4. After theÂ @Â symbol, add the recipientâ€™s cell phone carrier. See below for a list of cell phone carriers and their matchingÂ @Â addresses.Â         5. Type a short message in the body of the email. (A long message might be delivered in a barrage of multiple texts.)Â         6. ClickÂ Send. Your email will now be delivered as a text on the recipientâ€™s cell phone.Â         Â     Faxing from Email    1. ClickÂ New EmailÂ just like sending a regular email.        2. In the "To" section, enter the fax number followed by @fax.byui.edu.    When entering the fax number:        3. Type the message you would like faxed. If you would also like to include a file (document or image) in the fax, add it as an attachment. The body message will go through in the first page of the fax, and then the file you attached will come through on the next pages.    Faxing From a Printer:Â Faxing can also be done using a multifunctionÂ printer (copier) on Campus.Â Simply address theÂ To:Â in a Scan to Email the same way you would in Outlook for sending a Fax and let it scan your document. The scan will be included in the Fax.    Delaying Email    1. For the email you want to delay, expand theÂ TagsÂ section by clicking the arrow in the corner.        2. SelectÂ Do not deliver beforeÂ and enter the date and time you want the email to be sent. ClickÂ CloseÂ when done.        3. ClickÂ SendÂ to send the delayed email.

Tags: online security threats cyber-security report-spam report-phishing byui-report-phishing byui-report-spam outlook-desktop-app outlook-webapp
Paragraphs: Phishing emails are a type of online scam where criminals impersonate legitimate organizations via email to try to steal your sensitive information. As part of the ongoing effort to protect students, faculty, and staff against phishing emails and other cyber attacks, BYU-Idaho has partnered with the Church Educational System Security Operations Center (CESSOC).Â The CESSOC has a breadth of experience mitigating cyber threats and currently protects several other Church-sponsored institutions.    This article explains the procedure for reporting potential phishing emails to the CESSOC. It is important that the suspect phishing email is attached as an email file instead of forwarded.    Not sure if you've been phished? Check out the articleÂ Detecting Phishing.    Â     PreferredÂ Method    Using the "Report" Function in Outlook    If you suspected that you have received a phishingÂ email or other scam emails, keep all interactions with the email to a minimum. The best way to report these emails is to use the built-in "Report" Function of Microsoft Outlook.Â     When you preview an email you can select the "Report" drop-down menu. Select the "Report phishing" option.        After you have reported the email, and if you are worried about your information's security, you should change or reset your password. You can do this process yourself orÂ you can call or chat with the IT Service DeskÂ and they can help you with your password reset.    Â     Alternative Methods    If for whatever reason this process does not work for you you can follow the following instructions based on your way of accessing your school email. You can send the phishingÂ email, as an attachment, toÂ phishing@byui.eduÂ to report the phishingÂ or scam email.    Â     From theâ€¯OutlookÂ Webapp (accessed through your BYU-Idaho account)    1. Sign into your BYUI account and open the Outlook webapp.        2. In your Outlook inbox, selectÂ New Message.        3. After the new message opens, select theÂ Open in a new windowÂ button in the top right-hand corner of your new message.        4. After the new window opens, create a split screen between your email inbox and the new window so that both are visible. Address the new email toÂ phishing@byui.edu        5. In your inbox, click and drag the suspect phishing email over to the body text field of your new message draft.Â         6. You will see the phishing email appear as an attachment in the body of your new message draft.        7. ClickÂ Send. There is a Send button at the top and the bottom of the email draft, either one will work.        Â     From the Outlook Desktop App app on PC (installed and accessed on your desktop computer)    1. Open theÂ Outlook Desktop App.    2. Select the suspect phishing email in your inbox.        3. SelectÂ MoreÂ from theÂ RespondÂ section of the Home tab. This will open a drop-down menu with the optionÂ Forward as Attachment.        4. SelectÂ Forward as Attachment. This will open a new message draft in a new window with the suspicious email as an attachment.        5. Address the new message draft toÂ phishing@byui.edu.        6. ClickÂ Send.        Â     From the Outlook Desktop App on Mac (installed and accessed on your desktop computer)    1. Open the Outlook Desktop App        2. Find the suspect phishing email and right click the email.        3. SelectÂ Forward As AttachmentÂ from the drop-down menu.        3. A new message draft window will open with the suspicious email attached. Address the email toÂ phishing@byui.edu.        4. ClickÂ Send.

Paragraphs: Sharing your inbox with others can be helpful when you need someone to help you manage your emails or keep track of things while youâ€™re on vacation. If you would like someone else to also be the recipient of your Outlook emails, follow the steps below.Â Â     Microsoft Outlook    Steps for you to take    1.Â Right-click on the folder that you wish to share and selectÂ Permissions.        2. Select theÂ +.        3. Enter the name of the person with whom you wish to share the folder.Â ClickÂ Add.        4.Â Choose the permissions you wish to grant this person.â€¯Â ClickÂ OK. The folder you are searching for should now become accessible.

Header: Sharing Your Outlook Calendar and Adding Delegates
Tags: outlook-calendar automate-outlook-email sharing-electronic-calendar who-to-share-with accessing-shared-folder delegates share-calendar email-delegates delegate-to-your-account
Paragraphs: This article has information about how to share your Outlook calendar, who you should share your calendar with, how to access a shared calendar, and what delegates are.Â     Sharing your electronic calendar    1.Â Open your Outlook Email.Â     2.Â SelectÂ CalendarÂ from the bottom left corner.        3. Select the calendar you would like to share from the far left.        4.Â SelectÂ ShareÂ from the top right of the window.Â         5. Enter the email address or contact you would like to share with.        6. Click the drop-down menu next to the contact you have selected. Choose between the options to determine what permissions your contact might have for the calendar.        7. Click the drop-down menu next toÂ People in my organizationÂ and select which permissions you would like to allow.        8. ClickÂ Share.        Â     Who to share with    Be sure to only share your calendar with people (e.g. username@byui.edu) orâ€¯roles (e.g. departmentRole@byui.edu), not mailboxes (e.g. department@byui.edu).Â     Â     Accessing a shared folder    You will receive an email informing you that a calendar has been shared with you.Â SelectÂ Open CalendarÂ in the email.Â     Â     Delegates    Delegates in Outlook work similarly to office assistants that handle paper mail.Â When someone is listed as your delegate,Â they are able to receive and respond to e-mails and meeting requests on your behalf. The following steps will help you to make someone a delegate for your account:Â     1.Â SelectÂ theÂ FileÂ tab in Outlook.Â         2.Â SelectÂ Account Settings.Â         3.Â SelectÂ Delegate Access.Â         4. SelectÂ Add.Â         5.Â Type in the name (Last, First) of the person you wish to make into a delegate or enter the name into the search bar and then select it from the results list.Â         6.Â SelectÂ Add, thenÂ selectÂ OK.Â         7.Â A box will pop up asking you what kind of permissions you want to give your delegate. You may either choose to continue with the default settings, or you can manually change them to fit your needs.Â         8.Â SelectÂ the check box next toÂ Automatically send a message to delegate summarizing these permissionsÂ to send an email to your delegate informing them of their delegate status.Â         9.Â SelectÂ OK.        10. SelectÂ OKÂ to finalize the process.Â         Permissions    The personal details your delegates can view about you will vary depending on what permissions you give them. Permissions you may set include the following:Â     Availability Only: This permission shows that you have an event at a particular time, but no further information.Â     Limited Details: This permission will show the time, name, and location of the event.Â     Full Details: This permission will show all information about all events on your calendar, except for any that you might have marked asÂ Private.Â     Editor: This permission allows delegates to read and create calendar items on your behalf, and to change and/or delete items they create.Â     Changing a delegate's permissions    1.Â SelectÂ FileÂ on the Outlook desktop app menu.        2. SelectÂ Account Settings.Â         3.Â SelectÂ Delegate Access.Â         4.Â Choose the delegate you wish to change permissions for, thenÂ selectÂ Permissions....â€¯Â         5.Â A box will pop up asking you what kind of permissions you want to give your delegate. Use this pop up to determine what permissions you wish to give the delegate.Â         6.Â SelectÂ the check box next toÂ Automatically send a message to delegate summarizing these permissionsÂ to send an email to your delegate informing them of their delegate status.Â         7.Â SelectÂ OKÂ to finalize the process.

Slide Wi-Fi on, and then tapâ€¯Wi-Fi.        4. From the list of available networks that appear, choose theÂ BYUIâ€¯server.        5. TapÂ EAP Method. Be sure that the box is listedÂ PEAP.        6. TapÂ Phase 2 authenticationÂ and selectÂ MSCHAPv2Â orÂ Automatic.        7. TapÂ CA certificateÂ and selectÂ Do not validateÂ orÂ Do not checkÂ orÂ Trust on first use.        8. Type your BYUI username into theÂ IdentityÂ box and your BYUI password into theÂ PasswordÂ box. If you are asked to fill theÂ Anonymous IdentityÂ box, fill it in with anything you want.        Â     No Wi-Fi? Check if the Wi-Fi is on.    Check if your Wi-Fi is on by clicking the Wi-Fi symbol on your phone and finding the option to turn Wi-Fi on or off. If your Wi-Fi is not on, turn it on and try connecting to theÂ BYUIÂ network. Use theÂ Connect to the BYU-Idaho Wireless NetworkÂ section of this article if you need help.Â Â     You can also check for an external button that turns Wi-Fi on and off if you cannot locate a place to enable it in your phone settings.Â     Â     Howâ€™s your network connection?    If you are having problems accessing the BYU-Idaho website or I-Learn, see if you are connected to the BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi. This network is intended primarily for ecclesiastical leaders serving on campus and does not give access to I-Learn, printers, and other services.Â     You can see which network you are connected to by clicking the Wi-Fi icon located on your phone. If you are connected to the BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi, disconnect by clicking theÂ BYUI_VisitorÂ option, thenÂ Disconnect.Â     Â     Spotty Wi-Fi between buildings?    If you are having problems connecting to the campus Wi-Fi, your phone may be trying to connect to a network access point that is too far away. Disconnect from the Wi-Fi, then reconnect to theÂ BYUIÂ Wi-FiÂ network.

Tags: visitor-wifi BYUI-visitor byui-visitor-wifi visitor-wifi-access byui-visitor-blocks
Paragraphs: The BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi is intended primarily for ecclesiastical leaders serving on campus. This network allows bishops and stake presidents to process missionary applications and endorsements without the need to log into the campus network. In addition, this network may benefit other campus visitors like non-student dependents, parents of students, and various conference attendees.Â     The BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi network is filtered like other campus networks, and the types of websites accessible from this network are more limited than the current BYU-Idaho Wi-Fi. For example, popular streaming sites such as Netflix and Hulu are blocked.Â More importantly, Canvas cannot be accessed onÂ BYUI_VisitorÂ Wi-Fi.Â Users attempting to access a blocked site may see either an â€œApplication Blockedâ€ page or the page simply will not load. Because of the restrictions that have been imposed on the BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi, students and employees will find the current BYU-Idaho Wi-Fi to be better suited to their needs. They should not view the Visitor Wi-Fi as a non-authenticated replacement or an alternative.

Tags: wifi-terms wi-fi-terms wireless-terminology definition common-terminology
Paragraphs: Access Point:Â A radio device that acts as a gateway between wired networks and wireless clients. Similar to a â€œhub,â€ the access point is a common connection point for devices in a wireless network.Â     Bandwidth:Â The speed of a network connection commonly reported in Kilobits per second (Kbps) or Megabits per second (Mbps).Â     Client Adapter:Â Radio hardware installed in the client device (laptop, PDA,Â etc) that allows communication to and from an access point.Â     Connection Quality:Â Wireless connection quality is determined by factors that can affect radio transmissions, such as distance from the access point, number of users sharing bandwidth, state of the environment in which the transmission is taking place, and the presence of other devices that can cause interference. Acceptable throughput levels should be specified within service level agreements.Â     Coverage:Â The geographical area that covers an acceptable level of wireless activity, or the geographical area where good connection service quality is attainable.Â     Encryption:Â A method of scrambling and unscrambling data between one connection point to another, with the purpose of preventing unauthorized eyes from deciphering the data.Â     Interference:Â Degradation in wireless communications by any number of causes, such as other wireless devices, microwaves, handheld radios, cordless telephones, high voltage audio speakers, etc. Such interference usually slows down a wireless transmission or completely eliminate it depending on the strength of the signal.Â     User Authentication:Â A method by which the user of a wireless system can be verified as a legitimate user, independent of the computer or the operating system being used.Â     Wireless Infrastructure:Â Wireless access points, antennas, cabling, power, and network hardware associated with the deployment of a wireless communications network.

Paragraphs: Be wary when selecting a program, since some programs are actually viruses in disguise, designed to prey upon people's desire for antivirus protection.    Antivirus for University-issuedÂ Devices (applies to employees only)    All BYU-Idaho issues devices come pre-installed with antivirus software. If you're concerned that your device does not have this software, please contact the IT Service Desk, so we can help. Please note: some devices still have older software, such as Sophos installed. However, all employees are welcome to uninstall Sophos, if wanted.Â     Quality antivirus software    NOTE: Google the product you are considering. If results such as â€œremove [product name] appear,â€ it is probably a questionable application.    Recommended antivirus for Windows PC    While there are many kinds of antivirus software out there that areÂ safe to use, here are some examples of safe software to look into:    Recommended antivirus for Mac    While there are many kinds of antivirus software out there that are safe to use, here are some examples of safe software to look into:    Your computer might be infected if    How threats get on your computer    Your computer is vulnerable when:â€¯Â     How often you should back up your computer files    Anything can happen in the world of technology. It is vitalÂ that you back up your files constantly in order to prevent the loss of important documents. You can back up your files by saving them in many different forms, including:Â     BYU-Idaho offers OneDrive services to students. Tags: spam virus phishing-scam it-viruses virus-type virus-definition virus-explanation define-adware define-boot define-bug define-direct-action define-directory define-file-infector define-hijacker define-keylogger define-macro define-malware define-overwrite spyware trojan-horse worm
Paragraphs: Adware: Adware is among the most troublesome of computer threats. It can hide in places such as downloads for songs, movies, etc. Once installed on your computer, adware creates a flurry of advertisements and sends them directly to your computer. They can embed even more advertisements within the text of articles.    Direct Action: Direct action viruses begin their work as soon as they are installed on your computer. Typically, direct action viruses are designed to immediately activate/replicate when someone performs a specific action on a computer.    Directory: As its name would suggest, a directory virus attacks your computer by infiltrating its directory. (In computer terminology, a directory is just any big computer file that contains several smaller sub-files.) Typically, it will infect files with .EXEÂ for PC'sÂ or .DMGÂ for Mac extensions. Invisible to the user, a directory virus changes the host file so that the virus activates with the host file.    File Infector: File infectors are a classic virus; when someone refers to a generic virus, they are probably discussing these. These viruses spread from program to program by seeking out files to infect and then copying code into those files. Eventually, if left unchecked, file infectors can take over an entire system by compromising all of its files.    Hijacker: Hijacker viruses alter your Internet browser settings, typically in order to force your browser to redirect you to a page specified by the virus. These redirect pages are usually designed to advertise a product or drum up publicity for something/someone. They also alter the home page of your browser, spam you with unwanted advertisements, and block you from viewing Internet content.    Keylogger: Keyloggers place hidden software on your computer. This software keeps track of your keystrokes and takes note of the passwords you enter. Depending on what accounts you have, this can give hackers access to all kinds of private information.    Macro: Macro viruses contaminate individual programs on your computer. When a macro virus infects a program, it triggers a series of actions that will happen whenever someone runs the program.    Malware: Malware is any computer code that is designed to infiltrate a computer and damage it or its content.    Phishing Scam: Phishing occurs when you receive an email from a seemingly legitimate source asking for personal information like your Social Security Number or credit card number. Legitimate companies will never solicit this kind of information via email. If you receive an email asking for this information, delete the email immediately and report it toÂ the IT Service Desk. This is one of the most prevalent techniques used by hackers to steal your information, money, or data. Always be vigilantÂ for spam messages.Â     Ransomware: One of the most devastating or alarming forms of an attack. Bad actors can literally steal the data belonging to you on your device, work or school account, and hold is ransom from you. Most times, the ransom must be paid in a form of money (gift cards, Venmo, or Paypal). Good cyberÂ practices can protect you from ransomware. Most modern antivirusÂ programs will offer you protection against ransomware. And these antivirusÂ companies are spending time and energy to find ways to better protect against evolving ransomwareÂ attacks.Â     Spam: The term "spam" refers to emails sent with the intent of advertising something or getting you to click a link. At their best, spam emails are simply nuisances that clutter your inbox, and they can be dealt with by dragging-and-dropping theÂ message into the recycle bin. At their worst, they can promote illegal products/activities or conceal malware.    Spyware: Spyware is a form of malware that spies on your computer use. Spyware can take screen shots, capture data such as passwords and usernames, and collect other personal information. Keyloggers are just one example of spyware.    Trojan Horse: A Trojan horse is a virus that hides inside of something to make itself look enticing and appealing.    Virus: A virus is a type of malware that is designed to replicate and spread.    Worm: A worm is a form of virus that can copy itself and spread from computer to computer. It is not downloaded or attached to any one program; rather, it tunnels through computer networks in order to spread.    Check out the articlesÂ Antivirus Software TipsÂ andÂ Mac Viruses & Tips.

Tags: mac-viruses mac-tips common-mac-viruses fakeav flashback LEAP SAFE-MAC
Paragraphs: For many years, users held the belief that Apple devices are less prone to viruses. And to a certain extent, this was somewhat true. However, the unfortunate reality is that Apple devices (Macbooks, iPhones, iPads) can get viruses just as easily as Windows computers; they just vary in type, name, or design.Â As Macs grow in popularity and usage, so will security threats. That being the case, it is up to you to take the steps necessary to protect your computer from intruders. One of the best ways to protect your Apple device is byÂ utilizingÂ reputable antivirusÂ software, which is briefly covered in theÂ Antivirus Software TipsÂ article.Â     How can I keep my Mac safe?

Tags: FAQs frequently-asked-questions username-question password-question alumni-password alumni-username alumni-byui Account locked student-health-center disabled account-disabled 999-number social-security-number SSN-
Paragraphs: Why should I change my password frequently?    The ideal frequency for password-changing is every six months. When someone has your BYU-Idaho password, they have access to all your BYU-Idaho-associated records, includingâ€¯registration details, graduation progress, grades, email, and financial information. Some of this information can be destructive if it falls into the wrong hands.â€¯Â     A quick and easy way to prevent information theft is to change your password frequently. This keeps potential thieves and criminals guessing, which keeps your information safe. However, while itâ€™s smart to change your passwords frequently, do not change them too often. Changing passwords too frequently can result in weaker passwords that are easier for criminals to guess, which negates the security benefits offered by frequent password changes.Â Â     Â     How do I retrieve my forgotten username/password?    If you have forgotten your password, visit the â€¯Forgot Username or PasswordÂ page. Be prepared to provideâ€¯your Social Security Number (or 999 number if you are an international student), your last name, and your date of birth.    Â     How do I get a BYU-Idaho username or password for a new student or alumni?    New students    If you have been accepted to BYU-Idaho, but do not have a username or password yet, verify that you have accepted your admittance offer by visiting the response page. When the page loads, enter your CES NetID and password, and then follow the instructions on the next page.    Alumni    1. Go to www.byui.edu, and click theÂ Sign InÂ button.        2. SelectÂ Create usernameÂ and enter your personal information.        3. Follow the prompts to create a username and password and selectÂ Next.        4. Close out of your browser, then waitâ€¯one hourâ€¯for the system to update.Â     What if I get an error message when I try to log in after changing my password?    This could mean that your password change has not activated yet. Accounts usually take a minimum of one hour to activate. We ask you to be patient. If you have waited an hour or longer, contact the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411 or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble.    What should I do if my account is locked/disabled? Why is it locked?    There may be a number of reasons your account may be locked:    If you have more than 10 failed attempts in a row, you will receive the following error message, "Your account has been locked out due to excessive authentication failures."    Solution:Â Wait 5 minutes and your accountâ€¯will automatically be unlocked unless further failed attempts occur. If this doesn't resolve this issue, please contact the IT Service Desk.Â     The most common causes of locked accounts are unresolved student holds, such as student health center holds (TB test), unresolved debt, continuing endorsements, etc. For issues with holds from the Student Health Center, please contact the Student Health Center at 208-496-9330. For problems with other holds, please see ourÂ Resolve HoldsÂ webpage.    What if I do not have a security question on file or do not remember the answer to my security question?    If you do not have a security question or do not remember the answer to your security question, contact the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-9009 or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble for a temporary password reset.    How do I delete passwords from the Mac Keychain?    The Macâ€¯password management system is called theÂ Keychain. This system stores all your passwords for applications, servers, and websites. Keychains can also rememberâ€¯sensitive information such as credit card numbers or PINsâ€¯for bank accounts.â€¯Â     While saving your BYU-Idaho password to your Apple Keychain is convenient, saving this information makes your account susceptible to hackers. It is recommended that you remove your password from the Keychain for your safety.    1. OpenÂ Finder.    2. SelectÂ Applications.    3. SelectÂ Utilities.        4. SelectÂ Keychain Access.        5. TypeÂ byuiÂ into the search bar and pressÂ Enter.        6. When a list of search results appears, hold down theÂ ShiftÂ key, select the bottom result, and then pressÂ Delete.        7. Confirm by selectingÂ Delete.

Tags: Password FAQs change-password update-password security-questions secure-password strong-password password-requirements
Paragraphs: When creating a new password, you may need to forget the BYUI Wi-Fi network on your phone before proceeding. This will allow the phone to reconnect to the Wi-Fi. Check out the articleÂ Forgetting Wi-FiÂ for more information.    How to update passwords    Visit the articleÂ Changing BYU-Idaho PasswordsÂ to learn how to update or change your current password.    Updating BYU-Idaho password on several platforms    When you change your BYU-Idaho password, that password will need to be changed on every platform you use that password on. Visit the articleÂ Updating BYU-Idaho Password on Several PlatformsÂ to learn how to update your password across multiple platforms.    Â     Creating a more secure password    Hacking and password-cracking tools are becoming increasingly sophisticated, and the more personal information we store inâ€¯online accounts the more important it is to make sure our accounts are secure. The best place to start is with a strong password.Â     Password requirements    Passwords should be a collection of 12 or moreÂ     If your password is an ordinary word or name, a keyboard sequence, all letters, all lowercase, or fewer than 12 characters, you should change it to something stronger. Don't rely on tricky mixes of symbols, numbers, and uppercase letters alone. A mix of symbols, numbers, and uppercase letters makes a password stronger, but that alone wont make a simple password strong. For example,Â LetM3inÂ isn't much better than justÂ letmeinÂ when it comes to security.    Remember your password with a phrase    To keep it simple, stick with a word or phrase you know and remember. Add symbols or numbers in place of letters where it might make sense to you, but not to others. The key here is toâ€¯stay away from commonlyÂ used words or phrases, and to stay above 12 characters. Excellent passwords are long and complex, but easy to remember.Â Ideally,Â you are not using theÂ same password for multiple websites, so you will want to remember your passwords and keep them straight.Â     Strong passwords can also be created byâ€¯stringing unrelated words together in a way that's memorable to you because itâ€™s humorous (Inevitable culinary cat freedom,â€¯correct horse battery staple, etc.).â€¯While the entire phrase is long enough to be used as an effective password, a mix of numbers and symbols adds an extra layer of security.Â     Examples of strong passwords    How secure is my password?    Check out this website to see how secure different kinds of passwords are. Just input a fake password and the website will tell you how long it will take hackers to crack your password. For best results try a different combination of letters, numbers, symbols, and length. You may be surprised at the results!    How Secure Is My Password?    Â     Security questions    1. Go to go toÂ www.byui.eduÂ and select the button that saysÂ Sign In.    2. Even if your username and password are saved here, you will see the option toÂ Change PasswordÂ above the blueÂ LoginÂ button. SelectÂ Change Password.        3. SelectÂ Update Recovery InformationÂ from the options on the top row. It will have you sign in to your BYU-Idaho account and then automatically redirect you to the Security Information page.        4. Select the small arrow in the bar next toÂ Secret QuestionÂ and choose a security question from the drop-down menu.â€¯Â     5. Type your answer into the bar labeledÂ Secret Answer.    6. While you are here, make sure yourÂ Control EmailÂ is still accurate. Your control email is the email address you would like notifications regarding your password or secret question/answer sent to. This email must be different than your school email address.    7. When you are finished,â€¯selectÂ Submit.Â         Â     Frequently Asked Questions    Before asking for help, check out our FAQ page. You may find the answer you are looking for:Â Username & Password FAQs

Tags: bluetooth identity-theft login-credentials stolen-device lost-device mobile-worms phone-scam mobile-scam phone-threat mobile-precautions mobile-precaution vulnerable-applications location-services
Paragraphs: Mobile devices are everywhere. People use them for all kinds of things phone calls, texting, email, Web browsing, shopping, and more. Unfortunately, the rise in people using mobile devices for innocent purposes means there are now more people using them for criminal purposes.    Mobile worms    Mobile worms work very similar to computer worms. Rather than being transferred via downloads or infected USB drives, mobile worms spread by â€œtunnelingâ€ from one phone to another using wireless networks. They usually bury themselves within text messages or voicemails. The purpose of these worms is to manipulate your phone in ways that hike up your phone bill.Â     With the proper precautions youÂ canÂ protect yourself and your device. These precautions include:Â     Â     Vulnerable applications    Vulnerable applications are apps which require your personal information to operate, but do not encrypt (secure) that information properly. This leaves a lot of potential for identity theft and other crimes.    Â     Lost or stolen devices    Beside the immediate and obvious frustration of missing an important and expensive electronic, a lost or stolen phone or tablet can cause an enormous security risk. Depending on who falls into possession of the device, your information could be compromised.Â     Prevention is better than a cure. Set a passcode on your phone. Locked phones are less attractive to thieves than unlocked ones.Â IfÂ your phone goesÂ missing, the passcode will serve as an extra layer of protection for your information. Make sure your passwordÂ isÂ somewhat complicated, avoiding commonÂ codes like 1234 or 0000.Â     If you suspect your phone or tablet has been lost or stolen:

Paragraphs: There are many ways to keep yourself safe online.Â WithÂ safe computing practicesÂ in mind, you can have a good, risk-free experience onÂ the Internet andÂ social media. Have fun! Make sure to add BYU-Idaho ITâ€¯onÂ Facebook, Instagram,â€¯and Twitter while you are at it!Â     Identifying online threats    Always exercise conscientiousness and good judgement when it comes to opening emails and clicking links. Spam and phishing emails often give themselves away if you know what to look for, so keep an eye out for the following signs of phishing and spam:Â     Â     Online Dos & Don'ts    Common sense your first line defense in maintaining a safe, secure online presence. Here are some of the main dos and don'ts of social media and Internet use.    Do    Don't    Â     Securing your computer while using search engines    While search engines are treasure troves of information that certainly make our lives easier, they are also a breeding ground for criminals and malware infection. Some malware is specifically designed to hide within search results. WeÂ mustÂ learn to identify a suspicious link/website and avoid the malware lurking within it. Here are some ways to minimize the risk of contracting a computer virus and some things to watch for when navigating the wild world of the Internet.

Credit cards    Online shopping is easy and convenient, and it provides you with the opportunity to buy almost anything. However, it is important to understand that when you shop online and give outâ€¯sensitive information such as credit card numbers, there are security risks involved.Â     Tips for minimizing credit card fraud    Â     Social Security Numbers    Your Social Security Number (SSN) should always be kept safe. Paragraphs: ScammersÂ oftenÂ utilize social mediaÂ byÂ creating fake accountsÂ pretending to beÂ popular brands, organizations, celebrities, orÂ even your ownÂ friendsÂ toÂ try andÂ convince you to give them personal information and data. They can use this information to steal your money, includingÂ credit or debit card numbers, bank account numbers, usernames and passwords,Â etc.    One common tactic thatÂ these accountsÂ use is exploitingÂ realÂ giveaways. WhenÂ a real account startsÂ aÂ giveaway, scammersÂ willÂ create fake accountsÂ and seek out people who entered toÂ try to get theirÂ personal informationÂ by telling them that they won.Â Â     ToÂ identify fake accounts andÂ avoid being scammed over social media,Â checkÂ the following criteria:Â     Here is an example of aÂ real accountÂ that is being followed:        Here is an example of aÂ real account. Header: Using Outlook Rules to Find Viruses
Tags: create-rules outlook-rules outlook-viruses outlook-web outlook-desktop outlook-settings email-viruses reporting-email-viruses email-hackers unwanted-rules
Paragraphs: Today, Outlook provides more than just the sending and receiving of emails. It has a variety of tools that make managing emails easier. For example, there are Rules, Add-ons, and Templates. Unfortunately, there are people out there who use these great tools to worm their way in and steal your data.    Microsoft Outlook has a great system that looks for spam emails, but if you are still being bombarded by unwanted ads or your computer is acting slower than usual, it might be a good idea to check your Outlook Rules.    The following instructions will provide a step by step guidance on how to check Rules for lingering viruses.    How to check for viruses on Outlook Web    1. Log in to your Outlook Email at a the browser.    2. ClickÂ SettingsÂ in the top right corner.        3. ClickÂ View all Outlook settings.        4. ClickÂ Rules.        5. If you haven't created any Rules, your page should look like this:        6. If there are Rules, and you didn't create them, remove them immediately. Unless it is a Microsoft preset, it is a virus.    The example below is a hacker trying to get your information. Delete immediately.        7. To delete Rules, click theÂ Trash CanÂ orÂ DeleteÂ button to the right of the Rule.        7. ClickÂ OK.        8. You're all done! Finding and deleting Rules that don't belong there will help you be virus free.    Â     How to check for viruses on Outlook Desktop    1. Open Outlook on your desktop.    2. ClickÂ FileÂ in the top left corner.        3. ClickÂ Rules and Alerts.        4. If you have never created Rules, then your screen should look like this:        5. If there are Rules in this box that you did not create and they are not presets created by Outlook, they are most likely viruses. Delete immediately.    Here is an example of a suspicious Rule:        6. Select the Rule you want to delete. Don't click the check mark. The check mark turns the Rule on and off. Simply click the Rule directly.    ClickÂ Delete.        7. ClickÂ Yes.        8. You're all done! Finding and deleting Rules that don't belong there will help you be virus free.

Header: I Didnâ€™t Get a Push Notification
Tags: duo two-factor-authentication-2fa duo-ios duo-2fa duo-push-notifications push-notification-errors 2fa-notifications troubleshooting-duo internet-connectioin duo-android
Paragraphs: Here is a list of options to try if you do not receive a push notification after enrolling in yourÂ phone number.    iPhone    Enable notifications for the Duo Mobile app    When you first downloadâ€¯the app, a requestâ€¯appearsâ€¯asking you if you would like to allow Duo Mobile to send you notifications.â€¯You may have selected "Don'tâ€¯Allow" when this notification appeared, but you will have to allow notifications for the Duo Mobile app for it to work properly.â€¯    Toâ€¯allowâ€¯notifications for Duo Mobile:â€¯â€¯Â     1. Go toÂ Settings.â€¯Â         2. Scroll down and selectÂ Duo Mobile.â€¯Â         3. SelectÂ Notifications.â€¯â€¯Â         4. Allow notifications by tapping on the white toggle button.â€¯â€¯        Refreshing the Duo Mobile app    If you are allowing notifications for the Duo Mobile app but are still not receiving notifications, goâ€¯toâ€¯the Duo app andâ€¯pull down the screen. This will refresh your account and load all missing notifications. Approve the authentication request,â€¯and you are done.        Checking your internet connection    To use the Duo Mobile app, you will need a strongâ€¯Internetâ€¯connection. Try turning the Wi-Fi on and off to reset a wireless network that is having issues connecting to your device. If you have cellular data, turn off your Wi-Fiâ€¯and use data insteadâ€¯in order to get a betterâ€¯Internet connection.    Â     Android    This article is meant to help you troubleshoot problems with push notifications on an Androidâ€¯device.â€¯    Refreshing theâ€¯Duo Mobile app    Goâ€¯to the Duo Mobile appâ€¯andâ€¯pull down the screen. This will refresh your account and load all missing notifications.â€¯Find the notification you were trying to get and approve the authentication request.    Updating Google Play    If you are still not getting push notifications, you might need to check that Google Playâ€¯is updated.â€¯If Google Play is out-of-date, update it.    Clearing the Duo Mobile app cache    You can also clear the Duo Mobile app cacheâ€¯to try and free up any trapped notifications. To clear the Duo Mobile app cache:â€¯    1. Go toÂ Settings.â€¯    2. SelectÂ AppsÂ and scroll down to selectÂ Duo Mobile.â€¯Â         3. TapÂ Clear Cache.â€¯â€¯Â         Checking your Internet connection    If none ofâ€¯the previous stepsâ€¯work, check that you are using a strongâ€¯Internet connection. Try turning the Wi-Fi onâ€¯and off to reset theâ€¯wireless network. If you have cellular data, turn off your Wi-Fiâ€¯and use data instead in order to get a betterâ€¯Internet connection.

Paragraphs: What is a Bypass Code for DUO Mobile?    A bypass code is an authenticationÂ method reserved for people who cannot used DUOÂ Mobile in other traditional ways. i.eÂ  DUO Push Notification, a text message, phone call, etc.Â  It is a 9-digit-code that can be usedÂ to help be able to changeÂ Duo settings or get into your BYU-Idaho account.Â     Â     How Do I Get a Bypass Code?    In order to get a a bypass code you will need to talk to a member of the IT Service Desk. They will assess your situation and determine if you qualify for a Bypass code.    Depending on you circumstances, the bypass code you receiveÂ may have a limited amount of uses or only be used once. The IT Service Desk employee will help inform you about these conditions when you receive a Bypass code.Â     You may also be asked to verify you identity before the IT Service Desk employee can give you a bypass code. This is to ensure the safety of you account and stop any identity theft.

Paragraphs: Excessive Authentication Failures    If you are locked out of yourÂ DuoÂ account due to the error message: "Your account has been locked out due to excessive authenticationÂ failures. Please contact your administrator." (Shown below)        Please wait 60 minutes before contacting the IT Service Desk. Duo Mobile will put a temporary lock on your account due to what it assumes is suspicious account behavior. But after the 60-minute time period, your account should be unlocked. If your Duo account is locked a second time after the 60 minute timer, you may need to re-add your device, at this pointÂ feel free to contact the IT Service Desk.

Paragraphs: Disabling Content Restrictions    iOS 12 or newer    1. Navigate toÂ SettingsÂ >Â Screen TimeÂ >Â Content & Privacy RestrictionsÂ >Â Content RestrictionsÂ >Â Web Content    2. UncheckÂ Limit Adult WebsitesÂ to completely disable content restrictions.    - If you do not want to fully disable content restrictions, you can allowÂ duosecurity.comÂ within the Content Restrictions page on the iOS device. This will allow the Duo Prompt to display even if content restrictions are enabled.    iOS 11 or older    1. Go toÂ SettingsÂ >Â GeneralÂ >Â RestrictionsÂ >Â Websites    2. UncheckÂ Limit Adult ContentÂ to completely disable content restrictions.    macOS 10.15 (Catalina) or higher    1. OpenÂ System Preferences    2. Navigate toÂ Screen TimeÂ >Â Preferences > Content & Privacy    3. Set any Web Content restrictions toÂ Unrestricted access    - If you do not want to fully disable content restrictions, you can allowÂ duosecurity.comÂ within the Content Restrictions page on the iOS device or to the Allowed Websites Only list on macOS. This will allow the Duo Prompt to display even if content restrictions are enabled.

Header: How do I make an order through Canvas?
Tags: print-through-canvas I-Learn canvas print-from-canvas print-materials print-course-materials print-from-i-learn i-learn-print-materials how-to-print-canvas-materials
Paragraphs: If you are a student who prefers to read and mark-up school assignments on a printed sheet rather than a screen, you can now download and print out class materials through Canvas. Print & Copy Services is providing an easy, online ordering service for students and faculty called the Print Shop Pro WebDesk.    Students can download course materials, print them through Print & Copy Services, and pick them up on campus.    How do I make an order?    1. Log into your BYU-Idaho Canvas account.    2. Select theÂ on-campusÂ course you want to print materials from.        3. You will find the link on the left-hand column calledÂ Print Materials.Â If you have trouble finding it, contact your professor.        4. The Print Materials link will take you to the following page. Select the type of document you would like to print.        5. Check to make sure the order information is correct before proceeding.        6. Type the job name and the number of copies you wish to print.        7. Fill out the spaces below. If you have questions about a particular field, clickÂ What is this?.    ClickÂ ContinueÂ when done.        8. Select the order you want your document to be printed in. If there are special instructions, type them in the space below.    ClickÂ ContinueÂ when ready.        9. To attach the file you want to print, clickÂ Yes.        10. Download the course materials you want to print from Canvas onto your computer.    11. To attach a file, clickÂ Browse...Â         12. Locate the file you wish to print and clickÂ Open.        13. Select the type of file you attached.    If you have special instructions, type them in the box below.        14. Check the boxÂ I agree to the above statementÂ and clickÂ Attach File.    If your file is a PDF, steps 15-17 will not apply to you.        15. Your uploaded file will automatically be converted to a PDF. Review the document and clickÂ Close.        16. If the converted file changed important formatting like graphics or font sizes, click eitherÂ Not Approved - Make Changes and Send ProofÂ orÂ Not Approved - Make Changes and Proceed with Project (No Proof Necessary).    If the document looks fine, clickÂ OK As Is - Proceed with Project.        17. ClickÂ ContinueÂ when done.        18. If you selectedÂ Not Approved, the program will give you the option to make changes to your document and update the order. When you're done making changes, clickÂ Update Sort Order.    If you created a new file, clickÂ Attach Another File.        19. ClickÂ ContinueÂ when finished.        20. When your file is approved and ready, clickÂ Pay by Credit Card.        21. The second part of the page contains the shipping information.    Select the date you wish the project to be done by. Be mindful of the Print & Copy Services' business hours. For example, if you place an order Friday night, the earliest you can receive your order will be the following Monday.        22. When ready, clickÂ Finish. The user can alsoÂ Cancel OrderÂ orÂ Save As Quote.        23. Fill out the billing information and clickÂ Pay.        24. If your address does not match the address on your credit card, your payment will be declined. Double check to make sure the address on the credit card matches the address populated in the information        25. Your order will be processed, and you will be taken to the following screen. A confirmation email will be sent to your school email.        26. When your order is ready for pickup, an email will be sent to your school email.

Paragraphs: If you are a student who prefers to read and mark-up school assignments on a printed sheet rather than a screen, you can now download and print out class materials through Canvas. Tags: printer-not-working printer-jammed printer-does-not-print low-toner bad-print paper-jam poor-print-quality there-is-no-paper-in-printer print-from-browser no-print printer-took-money no-paper-in-printer document-could-not-be-printed scan scanning funds not-enough-funds
Paragraphs: This article will help you with the common issues a printer might have.    Printing directly from your browser    Whenever you print directly from the Internet, the printing job results are not guaranteed to look as expected. Printing directly from the Internet can cause inconsistent results due to web developers using different methods to keep their pages updated. If these pages are not updated properly, it can cause documents to print blank or as a collection of random characters. If it is vital that your printed document looksÂ the same as it does on the screen, it is highly recommended that you convert the document to a .pdf rather than attempt to print it directly from the Internet.    Â     Opening a document instead of saving    When youÂ OpenÂ a document in the web browser rather thanÂ SaveÂ it to your computer, computer-to-printer issues often result. This is because the document may not register as fully downloaded, which can sometimes cause inconsistencies with the printer. These inconsistencies usually cause the printer to print blank pages.Â     ToÂ resolveÂ this issue,Â download the document in question and saveÂ itÂ as aÂ .pdf before printing.    Â     Paper jam on campus    If the jam is easily visible and can be removed quickly and effortlessly, feel free to remove the jammed paper yourself by taking hold of it and slowly pulling it from the printer.Â Â     If you cannot see where the jam has occurred, or do not feel comfortable fixing the jam on your own, you can submit a ticket to I.T. and someone will come help you. You can also contact the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411 or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble.    Â     Poor print quality    If your printer is printing documents too lightly, make sure that the printer you are using is stocked with the appropriate paper for your print job. You may have to locate a printer that can correctly print your job.Â     It is also possible that the printer is low on toner or ink. Check the screen on the printer for a notification. To get help replacing the cartridges, you can submit a ticket to I.T. and someone will come help you. You can also contact the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411 or through theÂ Live ChatÂ bubble    Â     Printer took my money but didn't print    Check your Pharos account. If the print job is still uploaded to Pharos, it may be an issue with Pharos not releasing it. If the print job released from Pharos but nothing printed, then it is likely an issue with the printer.    If it's likely an issue with your Pharos account, contact the I.T. Service Desk at (208) 496-1411 or throughÂ theirÂ Live ChatÂ function.    If it's likely an issue with the printer, try another printer on campus and let the I.T. Service Desk know that that printer is having issues.    You can make a request for Printer Support throughÂ this form.    Â     Printer out of paper    To request more paper for this printer, contact the I.T. Service DeskÂ at (208) 496-1411 or throughÂ theirÂ Live ChatÂ function.Â They will be able to service the printer.    Â     Print job failed to print    If you you try to print a document and nothing happens or you get an error that the document could not be printed, follow the steps below.    Word and Powerpoint files    A Tip for more successful printing of Word (doc or docx files) and PowerPoint (pptx) files:Â Â     While the print system can print Word and PowerPoint files, the content embedded in a Word or PowerPoint file (especially PowerPoint files) can cause issues with printing.Â  Therefore, outputting the Word or PowerPoint file as a PDF reduces the embedded content to actual document size, then the second PDF generation (using a web browser) has the effect of "flattening" the file, reducing the file's internal complexity and making it more 'print friendly' without losing the quality of print.    More Complex PDF Files    A Tip for more successful printing of 'more complex' PDF files:Â Â     Many PDF files (especially forms like tax forms, documents with a lot of legalese, or multiple embedded images) will have a fair amount of embedded content in the document that has not been suitably prepared for printing, resulting in files that either take a very long time to print each page or may not print at all.Â  By using a web browser to 'print' as a new PDF, the output is more "flattened" and the internal content is no longer as complex as only the content that is viewable remains, thus making a file that is more 'print friendly' without losing the quality of print.

A dialog box will appear. When prompted, enter your username and password for your BYU-Idaho account, then selectÂ Login.        6. A box will appear notifying that your account has been opened. Paragraphs: The Favorites section of Outlook, located at the top of the Navigation Panel, contains shortcuts to folders such as your Inbox, Sent Items, and Search Folders. You can add, remove, and arrange folders in this section in order to access your mail folders more easily.    When a folder is added to Favorites, a shortcut is created; however, the folder and its contents remain at their original location in the folder list. Removing a folder from Favorites does not delete the folder or the contents - it removes only the shortcut that appears in Favorites.    Adding a folder to favorites    1.Â Locate the folder that you want to add to Favorites, then right-click it.Â         2. In the drop-down menu that appears, selectÂ Add to Favorites.Â         Â     Removing a folder from favorites    1.Â Go into yourÂ FavoritesÂ folder.Â         2. Locate the folder that you want to remove, then right-click it.Â     3.Â In the drop-down menu that appears,Â selectÂ Remove from Favorites.

Tags: blocked blocked-emails quarantined unblock-emails quarantined-emails quarantine-settings
Paragraphs: We've partnered with Microsoft Office 365's Exchange Online Protection (EOP) to automatically quarantine highly-suspicious messages at the server level before they even reach yourâ€¯Inboxâ€¯orâ€¯Junk E-mailâ€¯folder.Â You will occasionally receive a message from quarantine@messaging.microsoft.com indicating that you have X (number) of new spam-quarantined messages.Â (see the instructions below to review messages even if you don't receive this email)    You will be given the following three options for each email:    Release to Inbox    This sends the message to your regular inbox. This is usually used to review the message in more detail to determine whether it's something that you want to continue to allow us to quarantine, whether you can safely unsubscribe from the message, or whether you want to report to us that it is not - in fact - junk.    Report as Not Junk    This sends a copy of the message to the support team for analysis. If you're certain that the message should not have been quarantined - based on your review of theâ€¯Senderâ€¯andâ€¯Subjectâ€¯from the report and/or from having used the "Release to Inbox"â€¯link to review it in more detail - this is how you'd let us know that you don't want these messages quarantined in the future.    "This client requires a certificate"    If you're on a Mac usingâ€¯Safariâ€¯as your default browser, you may need to make a change to a certificate in order to avoid the "This client requires a certificate" message. â€¯Here's aÂ Microsoft Support articleÂ explaining how to do that.    Â     Reviewing Quarantined Emails    If you are having trouble using the quarantine portal on Safari, followÂ these steps.Â         Â     Editing Quarantine Settings        2. Â  Â Click the "+ Add" under the respective field (if you scroll up you should see a similar heading regarding "Blocked senders and domains" if that is what you would like to do).

Paragraphs: There are lots of functions the Outlook Desktop can do. Select the section you want to learn more about.    For instructions on how to combine school and personal email see the articleÂ Setting Up Email on a Mobile Device.    Texting from Email    If you need to get a message to someone who might not have access to their email, you can text them from your own email.Â     1. OpenÂ Outlook.Â     2. ClickÂ NewÂ EmailÂ orÂ New MessageÂ to compose a new draft.        3. Enter the recipientâ€™s ten-digit cell phone number in theÂ To:Â field, followed by theÂ @Â symbol.    4. After theÂ @Â symbol, add the recipientâ€™s cell phone carrier. See below for a list of cell phone carriers and their matchingÂ @Â addresses.Â         5. Type a short message in the body of the email. (A long message might be delivered in a barrage of multiple texts.)Â         6. ClickÂ Send. Your email will now be delivered as a text on the recipientâ€™s cell phone.Â         Â     Faxing from Email    1. ClickÂ New EmailÂ just like sending a regular email.        2. In the "To" section, enter the fax number followed by @fax.byui.edu.    When entering the fax number:        3. Type the message you would like faxed. If you would also like to include a file (document or image) in the fax, add it as an attachment. The body message will go through in the first page of the fax, and then the file you attached will come through on the next pages.    Faxing From a Printer:Â Faxing can also be done using a multifunctionÂ printer (copier) on Campus.Â Simply address theÂ To:Â in a Scan to Email the same way you would in Outlook for sending a Fax and let it scan your document. The scan will be included in the Fax.    Delaying Email    1. For the email you want to delay, expand theÂ TagsÂ section by clicking the arrow in the corner.        2. SelectÂ Do not deliver beforeÂ and enter the date and time you want the email to be sent. ClickÂ CloseÂ when done.        3. ClickÂ SendÂ to send the delayed email.

Tags: online security threats cyber-security report-spam report-phishing byui-report-phishing byui-report-spam outlook-desktop-app outlook-webapp
Paragraphs: Phishing emails are a type of online scam where criminals impersonate legitimate organizations via email to try to steal your sensitive information. As part of the ongoing effort to protect students, faculty, and staff against phishing emails and other cyber attacks, BYU-Idaho has partnered with the Church Educational System Security Operations Center (CESSOC).Â The CESSOC has a breadth of experience mitigating cyber threats and currently protects several other Church-sponsored institutions.    This article explains the procedure for reporting potential phishing emails to the CESSOC. It is important that the suspect phishing email is attached as an email file instead of forwarded.    Not sure if you've been phished? Check out the articleÂ Detecting Phishing.    Â     PreferredÂ Method    Using the "Report" Function in Outlook    If you suspected that you have received a phishingÂ email or other scam emails, keep all interactions with the email to a minimum. The best way to report these emails is to use the built-in "Report" Function of Microsoft Outlook.Â     When you preview an email you can select the "Report" drop-down menu. Select the "Report phishing" option.        After you have reported the email, and if you are worried about your information's security, you should change or reset your password. You can do this process yourself orÂ you can call or chat with the IT Service DeskÂ and they can help you with your password reset.    Â     Alternative Methods    If for whatever reason this process does not work for you you can follow the following instructions based on your way of accessing your school email. You can send the phishingÂ email, as an attachment, toÂ phishing@byui.eduÂ to report the phishingÂ or scam email.    Â     From theâ€¯OutlookÂ Webapp (accessed through your BYU-Idaho account)    1. Sign into your BYUI account and open the Outlook webapp.        2. In your Outlook inbox, selectÂ New Message.        3. After the new message opens, select theÂ Open in a new windowÂ button in the top right-hand corner of your new message.        4. After the new window opens, create a split screen between your email inbox and the new window so that both are visible. Address the new email toÂ phishing@byui.edu        5. In your inbox, click and drag the suspect phishing email over to the body text field of your new message draft.Â         6. You will see the phishing email appear as an attachment in the body of your new message draft.        7. ClickÂ Send. There is a Send button at the top and the bottom of the email draft, either one will work.        Â     From the Outlook Desktop App app on PC (installed and accessed on your desktop computer)    1. Open theÂ Outlook Desktop App.    2. Select the suspect phishing email in your inbox.        3. SelectÂ MoreÂ from theÂ RespondÂ section of the Home tab. This will open a drop-down menu with the optionÂ Forward as Attachment.        4. SelectÂ Forward as Attachment. This will open a new message draft in a new window with the suspicious email as an attachment.        5. Address the new message draft toÂ phishing@byui.edu.        6. ClickÂ Send.        Â     From the Outlook Desktop App on Mac (installed and accessed on your desktop computer)    1. Open the Outlook Desktop App        2. Find the suspect phishing email and right click the email.        3. SelectÂ Forward As AttachmentÂ from the drop-down menu.        3. A new message draft window will open with the suspicious email attached. Address the email toÂ phishing@byui.edu.        4. ClickÂ Send.

Tags: microsoft-outlook sharing-inbox sharing-outlook-inbox how-to-share-my-inbox multiple-recipients
Paragraphs: Sharing your inbox with others can be helpful when you need someone to help you manage your emails or keep track of things while youâ€™re on vacation. If you would like someone else to also be the recipient of your Outlook emails, follow the steps below.Â Â     Microsoft Outlook    Steps for you to take    1.Â Right-click on the folder that you wish to share and selectÂ Permissions.        2. Select theÂ +.        3. Enter the name of the person with whom you wish to share the folder.Â ClickÂ Add.        4.Â Choose the permissions you wish to grant this person.â€¯Â ClickÂ OK.        Â     Steps for your recipient to take    1. SelectÂ File.    2. SelectÂ Open.Â     3.Â SelectÂ OtherÂ Userâ€™s Folder.Â     4.Â Enter the name of the person sharing the folder. The folder you are searching for should now become accessible.

Header: Sharing Your Outlook Calendar and Adding Delegates
Tags: outlook-calendar automate-outlook-email sharing-electronic-calendar who-to-share-with accessing-shared-folder delegates share-calendar email-delegates delegate-to-your-account
Paragraphs: This article has information about how to share your Outlook calendar, who you should share your calendar with, how to access a shared calendar, and what delegates are.Â     Sharing your electronic calendar    1.Â Open your Outlook Email.Â     2.Â SelectÂ CalendarÂ from the bottom left corner.        3. Select the calendar you would like to share from the far left.        4.Â SelectÂ ShareÂ from the top right of the window.Â         5. Enter the email address or contact you would like to share with.        6. Click the drop-down menu next to the contact you have selected. Choose between the options to determine what permissions your contact might have for the calendar.        7. Click the drop-down menu next toÂ People in my organizationÂ and select which permissions you would like to allow.        8. ClickÂ Share.        Â     Who to share with    Be sure to only share your calendar with people (e.g. username@byui.edu) orâ€¯roles (e.g. departmentRole@byui.edu), not mailboxes (e.g. department@byui.edu).Â     Â     Accessing a shared folder    You will receive an email informing you that a calendar has been shared with you.Â SelectÂ Open CalendarÂ in the email.Â     Â     Delegates    Delegates in Outlook work similarly to office assistants that handle paper mail.Â When someone is listed as your delegate,Â they are able to receive and respond to e-mails and meeting requests on your behalf. The following steps will help you to make someone a delegate for your account:Â     1.Â SelectÂ theÂ FileÂ tab in Outlook.Â         2.Â SelectÂ Account Settings.Â         3.Â SelectÂ Delegate Access.Â         4. SelectÂ Add.Â         5.Â Type in the name (Last, First) of the person you wish to make into a delegate or enter the name into the search bar and then select it from the results list.Â         6.Â SelectÂ Add, thenÂ selectÂ OK.Â         7.Â A box will pop up asking you what kind of permissions you want to give your delegate. You may either choose to continue with the default settings, or you can manually change them to fit your needs.Â         8.Â SelectÂ the check box next toÂ Automatically send a message to delegate summarizing these permissionsÂ to send an email to your delegate informing them of their delegate status.Â         9.Â SelectÂ OK.        10. SelectÂ OKÂ to finalize the process.Â         Permissions    The personal details your delegates can view about you will vary depending on what permissions you give them. Permissions you may set include the following:Â     Availability Only: This permission shows that you have an event at a particular time, but no further information.Â     Limited Details: This permission will show the time, name, and location of the event.Â     Full Details: This permission will show all information about all events on your calendar, except for any that you might have marked asÂ Private.Â     Editor: This permission allows delegates to read and create calendar items on your behalf, and to change and/or delete items they create.Â     Changing a delegate's permissions    1.Â SelectÂ FileÂ on the Outlook desktop app menu.        2. SelectÂ Account Settings.Â         3.Â SelectÂ Delegate Access.Â         4.Â Choose the delegate you wish to change permissions for, thenÂ selectÂ Permissions....â€¯Â         5.Â A box will pop up asking you what kind of permissions you want to give your delegate. Use this pop up to determine what permissions you wish to give the delegate.Â         6.Â SelectÂ the check box next toÂ Automatically send a message to delegate summarizing these permissionsÂ to send an email to your delegate informing them of their delegate status.Â         7.Â SelectÂ OKÂ to finalize the process.

Paragraphs: Students and employees of BYU-Idaho as well asÂ Pathway Worldwide studentsÂ can download and install Microsoft Office 365 for freeÂ by following the instructions outlined below. Office 365    1.Â Visit the University Store'sÂ Download Microsoft OfficeÂ page and selectÂ Download.Â This link will take you to Microsoft's website.    2. Here, under "Apps and Devices," click Install Office. This will start the download of Office.        The following steps vary depending on whether you are using a PC or a Mac.    For PC,Â Click Here    For Mac,Â Click Here    Installing on PC    6. Open the download file to begin installation.    7. Tags: Outlook-Email outlook-rules outlook-web creating-rules-in-outlook automate-outlook-email rules-outlook email-rules creating-rules creating-email-rules add-new-rule
Paragraphs: Each email client (such as Outlook, Gmail, or Apple Mail) has their own name and system for creating "Rules". These Rules are automated instructions the system follows, which can do a number of things.    For example, you can send emails from a specific person directly to a folder instead of the inbox, send emails containing the subject "BYU-Idaho" to a specific folder, or even place any emails that contain the word "cat" into your funny cats folder. All you need is to create Outlook Rules.    Creating Rules on Outlook Web    Since there are many ways to create and use rules, this tutorial will go over one of the options. In this case, we will move all emails with the subject line "BYU-Idaho" to the folder "BYU-Idaho News."    1. Log in to your Outlook Email.    2. Click theÂ SettingsÂ icon (gear icon) in the top right corner.        3. ClickÂ View all Outlook settings.        4. ClickÂ Rules.        5. If you haven't created any rules, your page should look like this:    6. Click +Â Add new rule.        7. Type in the name of the rule you want to make. In this case, type "BYU-Idaho News."        8. Add a condition. Conditions tell the computer what to look for. As you can see, there are many conditions you could set.    For this example, clickÂ Subject includesÂ because we are only looking for emails containing "BYU-Idaho" in the subject line.        9. In the box to the right, fill in the phrase we are looking for. In this case, we are looking for "BYU-Idaho".        10. Select an action.    An action tells the computer what to do when a condition is met. But, as mentioned, there are dozens of options to choose from. You can make these Rules do practically anything.    In this case, selectÂ Move toÂ because we are moving an email from the inbox to the BYU-Idaho News folder.        11. Select the folder you want to place the email in. Since you probably don't have this folder, scroll down to selectÂ New folder.        12. Type "BYU-Idaho News" in the New Folder box and clickÂ Enter.        13. Your page should now look like this:        14. If this option shows up (sometimes it doesn't), selectÂ Run rule now.Â Then, clickÂ Save.        15. You can turn a rule on and off whenever you like by selecting theÂ Blue ToggleÂ button to the left of the rule.        You're all done! Think of all the possibilities with your Rule tool!    Unfortunately, these neat tools can be used by hackers. Can you see now how someone may use these tools to create Rules that hide or steal important information from you? Remember to frequently check your rules for suspicious activity. If you didn't create a rule and you don't know what it does, it is probably a virus. Delete it immediately.    If your rules are not functioning, seeÂ this article.    For more information on viruses and rules, check out our other article:Â Using Outlook Rules to Find Viruses.

Tags: outlook-app Outlook-Email outlook-rules outlook-desktop creating-rules-in-outlook automate-outlook-email rules-outlook creating-rules creating-email-rules add-new-rule
Paragraphs: Each email client (such as Outlook, Gmail, or Apple Mail) has their own name and system for creating "Rules". These Rules are automated instructions the system follows, which can do a number of things.    For example, you can send emails from a specific person directly to a folder instead of the inbox, send emails containing the subject "BYU-Idaho" to a specific folder, or even place any emails that contain the word "cat" into your funny cats folder. All you need is to create Outlook Rules.    Since there are many ways to create and use Rules, this tutorial will go over one of the options. In this case, we will move all emails with the subject line "BYU-Idaho" to the folder "BYU-Idaho News".    1. Open Outlook on your desktop.    2. ClickÂ FileÂ in the top left corner.        3. ClickÂ Rules and Alerts.        4. If you have never created rules, your screen should look like this:        5. ClickÂ New Rule.        6. TheÂ Rules WizardÂ box will appear. This will provide you with some templates. Take some time to read through those to see if any of them are what you need. Remember, there are dozens of tools and options for creating rules. Use this tutorial as a guide to learning how the rules work.    7. SelectÂ Apply rule on messages I receiveÂ and clickÂ Next.        8. SelectÂ with specific words in the subject.Â In the box below, it will explain what this condition is doing. Click the linkÂ specific wordsÂ to select the name or group you wish to use. In this case, we will search for emails with the subject "BYU-Idaho".        9. Type the subject you want the computer to look for. In this case, typeÂ "BYU-Idaho".Â ClickÂ AddÂ when done.        10. ClickÂ OK.        11. SelectÂ move it to the specified folder,Â since we want to move all emails with the subject "BYU-Idaho" to the folder, "BYU-Idaho News". Then click the linkÂ specified.    Keep in mind that there are a lot of actions to choose from. You can make this as personalized as you need.        12. If you have already created the folder "BYU-Idaho News", click the folder. If you have not, clickÂ New.        13. TypeÂ BYU-Idaho NewsÂ in the box. ClickÂ OK.        14. TheÂ BYU-Idaho NewsÂ folder should be highlighted. ClickÂ OK.        15. The name of the folder and what we are looking for in the subject line should show up in the lower box.    Since we have no other parameters, clickÂ Next.        16. If you would like to make any exceptions to this action, select the ones you want. For example, if you want all emails from Windy Weather sent to your folder, except the ones with the word "tornadoes", you can make those adjustments here. When you're done, clickÂ Next.        17. Don't forget to haveÂ Turn on this ruleÂ selected, to turn on the rule. If you want this rule to happen to mail already inside your inbox, selectÂ Run this rule now on messages already inÂ "Inbox".    When you're done, clickÂ Finish.        18. You're all done! Think of all the possibilities you can do with your Rule tool! Can you see now how hackers can use these tools to create rules that hide or steal important information from you? Remember to frequently check your rules for suspicious activity. If you didn't create a rule and you don't know what it does, it is probably malware. Delete it immediately.    If your rules isn't functioning, seeÂ this article.    For more information on viruses and Rules, check out our other article:Â Using Outlook Rules to Find Viruses..

Tags: create-rules outlook-web outlook-desktop email-rules creating-email-rules add-new-rule outlook-rule-errors rule-error outlook-rule refresh-outlook outlook-login rule-not-working
Paragraphs: If you created a new rule, and it is not functioning the way you wanted it to, here are a few suggestions.    1. Check to make sure the rule you made doesn't contain any mistakes like a misspelled word or incorrectly selected action.    2. Refresh your Outlook page.    3. Log out of Outlook and log back in again.    4. If you use the web-based Outlook (where it appears as a tab on whatever Internet browser you use), having the rule apply to messages already in your inbox does not work. After you have created the rule, any new mail that comes in will function properly. If the immediate functionality of the rule is important, download the desktop version of Outlook and take a look at your rules there. The desktop version of Outlook functions normally for messages already in the inbox.

Tags: mass-emails bcc blind-carbon-copy email-policy mass-recipients
Paragraphs: Mass email policy    Officially, emails that consist of more than 500 recipients per message cannot be sent or received through a BYU-Idaho email account. Additionally, the BYU-Idaho account limits emails to 10,000 recipients per day. Sending a lot of emails in a short period of time to a wide list of users may qualify you for being blocked.    Even though our stated limit is 500 recipients per message and 10,000 recipients per day, Microsoft has identified a limit that we do not share to avoid spammers. If spammers were to find the Microsoft limit, they would use it to stay within the lines of credulity to bypass our security. We advise pacing your sending to a longer period or investigating using mass mailing software such as the one that University Relations utilizes in order to get a better through-rate, in addition to better analytics.    Â     Exceptions    Exceptions to this policy are intended only for explicitly-authorized senders. This includes the following:Â     Â     Procedure    When sending approved mass emails from your BYU-Idaho account or to BYU-Idaho recipients (students, faculty, staff, and alumni), campus procedure strongly encourages that you use the "bcc" (Blind Carbon Copy) option.    Â     Using Bcc    What is Bcc?    "Bcc" is the practice of sending an email to multiple recipients without disclosing the complete list of recipients.    When should I use Bcc?    You should "Bcc" when:Â     How do I send an email with Bcc?    1. When sending a new email message, selectÂ Cc.        2. In the pop-up window that appears, enter the email addresses of all recipients into theÂ BccÂ section at the bottom.        3. Once you have entered the desired email addresses, selectÂ OK.        4. Write the email andÂ selectÂ Send.
