This article includes solutions to problems you may face in the event that your password does not successfully sync and update at first.Â     To learn more about passwords, visit the articleÂ Username & Password FAQs.    If you have previously synced your BYU-Idaho password to your Mac iOS keychain, you may receive continual popups that an application or file requires an updated keychain password. The following steps will help you update your keychain password:    1. Open theÂ Launchpad.        2. Search for and openÂ Keychain Access.        3. OpenÂ Preferences.Â         4. ClickÂ Reset My Default Keychains.        5. Enter your updated password, and clickÂ OK.Â         6. ClickÂ OK.

Header: Updating BYU-Idaho Password on Several Platforms
Tags: Password updating-password password-update microsoft-password different-devices password-repositories desktop-apps internet-browsers
Paragraphs: Because your BYU-Idaho account allows you access to several different programs and softwares, it may take some time for your password to update throughout the entire system. This article includes solutions to problems you may face in the event that your password does not successfully sync and update at first.Â     To learn more about passwords, visit the articleÂ Username & Password FAQs.    Microsoft desktop Apps    If your Microsoft Office desktop apps are not syncing with your new password automatically, you may see a yellow bar near the top of the screen asking you to sign in, a yellow warning sign in the upper right-hand corner, or your document might say â€œUpload Blockedâ€ after the title of the document on the top of the window.    1. ClickÂ File, thenÂ Account.    2. ClickÂ Sign OutÂ found under your name.    3. Close all Microsoft Office desktop app and then reopen one, such as Word or Excel.    4. ClickÂ File, thenÂ Account.Â ThenÂ Sign In.    Once you have done this in one Microsoft Office desktop app, the change should be seen across all Microsoft Office desktop apps. You may need to do this for other Microsoft Office desktop apps that are a different version. For example, if you make the change in Office 2016, but have OneNote 2013 on your computer, the change may not be seen by Office 2013 and you will need to repeat the process for Office 2013.    Â     BYUI campus devices    There are several campus devices that require BYU-Idaho credentials in order to complete requests (e.g. printers, campus computers). Because these devices are directly linked to the University's system, their credential requirement should update automatically. Simply sign in with your updated password.Â     In the event that your new password hasn't yet updated in the system, use the following process:    1. Make sure the device is connected to the BYUI Wi-Fi network.Â     2. Log in using your previous password.    3. Restart the device.    4. Log in using your updated password.    Â     Password repositories    Just as with internet browsers and password keychains, each password repository that includes your BYU-Idaho password will need to be manually updated. You can find instructions on how to update your password within your respective password repository's website.Â     Â     Internet browsers    If you have saved your BYU-Idaho password to your internet browser, you will need to update it by visiting your browser's settings. Some browsers, like Chrome and Safari, will ask if you would like to update your settings after you log in with your updated password. Confirm that you would when this option appears.Â     Â     Other software requiring BYU-Idaho credentials    Some software, both internal and external, will not automatically sync your updated password. This includes any third-party account for which BYU-Idaho email and password are used to authenticate. For these instances, simply update your password through that specific account's settings.

Header: Updating BYU-Idaho Password on the Wi-Fi
Tags: wi-fi byui-wifi new-password update-wifi-password internet-password byui-internet wifi-android wifi-iphone
Paragraphs: Because your BYU-Idaho account allows you access to several different programs and software, it may take some time for your password to update throughout the entire system. This article includes solutions to problems you may face in the event that your password does not successfully sync and update at first.Â     To learn more about passwords, visit the articleÂ Username & Password FAQs.    After changing your BYU-Idaho password, you may have some difficulty connecting to the wireless network. Since your access to the university Wi-Fi is your BYU-Idaho credentials, your login information is technically no longer correct. You can easily fix this by updating your password in your device settings.Â Â     Difference between the BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi and the BYU-Idaho Wi-Fi    The BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi is intended primarily for ecclesiastical leaders serving on campus. This network allows bishops and stake presidents to process missionary applications and endorsements without the need to log into the campus network. In addition, this network may benefit other campus visitors like non-student dependents, parents of students, and various conference attendees. Â     The BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi network is filtered like other campus networks, and the types of websites accessible from this network are more limited than the current BYU-Idaho Wi-Fi. For example, popular streaming sites such as Netflix and Hulu are blocked. More importantly, Canvas cannot be accessed on BYUI_Visitor Wi-Fi. Users attempting to access a blocked site may see either an â€œApplication Blockedâ€ page or the page simply will not load. Because of the restrictions that have been imposed on the BYU-Idaho Visitor Wi-Fi, students and employees will find the current BYU-Idaho Wi-Fi to be better suited to their needs. They should not view the Visitor Wi-Fi as a non-authenticated replacement or an alternative.    Â     Updating Wi-Fi password on an iPhone    1. OpenÂ SettingsÂ and tapÂ Wi-Fi.        2. Select theÂ BYUIÂ network.        3. TapÂ Forget This Network. You will then be asked to verify that you would like to forget the network. TapÂ Forget This NetworkÂ again to forget the network and erase your old password from automatically trying to connect your iPhone to the wireless network.        4. Repeat steps 1â€“2.        5. You will be asked to provide a username and password. Type in your BYU-Idahoâ€¯username along withâ€¯your new password. TapÂ Join.        6. TapÂ TrustÂ to finalize joining the network.        Â     Â     Updating Wi-Fi password on an Android    1. Scroll down from the top screen and TapÂ Settings.        2. TapÂ Network & internet.        3. Tapâ€¯Wi-Fi.        4. From the list of available networks that appear, choose theÂ BYUIâ€¯server.        5. UnderÂ CA CertificationÂ selectÂ Do not validate.        6. Putâ€¯your username and password in for the BYU-Idaho wireless network.

Enter your BYU-Idaho email, then tapÂ Add Account.        3. You will be directed to BYU-Idaho's login page. Enter your BYU-Idaho username and password and tapÂ Login. Tags: Outlook-Email outlook-rules outlook-web creating-rules-in-outlook automate-outlook-email rules-outlook email-rules creating-rules creating-email-rules add-new-rule
Paragraphs: Each email client (such as Outlook, Gmail, or Apple Mail) has their own name and system for creating "Rules". These Rules are automated instructions the system follows, which can do a number of things.    For example, you can send emails from a specific person directly to a folder instead of the inbox, send emails containing the subject "BYU-Idaho" to a specific folder, or even place any emails that contain the word "cat" into your funny cats folder. All you need is to create Outlook Rules.    Creating Rules on Outlook Web    Since there are many ways to create and use rules, this tutorial will go over one of the options. In this case, we will move all emails with the subject line "BYU-Idaho" to the folder "BYU-Idaho News."    1. Log in to your Outlook Email.    2. Click theÂ SettingsÂ icon (gear icon) in the top right corner.        3. ClickÂ View all Outlook settings.        4. ClickÂ Rules.        5. If you haven't created any rules, your page should look like this:    6. Click +Â Add new rule.        7. Type in the name of the rule you want to make. In this case, type "BYU-Idaho News."        8. Add a condition. Conditions tell the computer what to look for. As you can see, there are many conditions you could set.    For this example, clickÂ Subject includesÂ because we are only looking for emails containing "BYU-Idaho" in the subject line.        9. In the box to the right, fill in the phrase we are looking for. In this case, we are looking for "BYU-Idaho".        10. Select an action.    An action tells the computer what to do when a condition is met. But, as mentioned, there are dozens of options to choose from. You can make these Rules do practically anything.    In this case, selectÂ Move toÂ because we are moving an email from the inbox to the BYU-Idaho News folder.        11. Select the folder you want to place the email in. Since you probably don't have this folder, scroll down to selectÂ New folder.        12. Type "BYU-Idaho News" in the New Folder box and clickÂ Enter.        13. Your page should now look like this:        14. If this option shows up (sometimes it doesn't), selectÂ Run rule now.Â Then, clickÂ Save.        15. You can turn a rule on and off whenever you like by selecting theÂ Blue ToggleÂ button to the left of the rule.        You're all done! Think of all the possibilities with your Rule tool!    Unfortunately, these neat tools can be used by hackers. Can you see now how someone may use these tools to create Rules that hide or steal important information from you? Remember to frequently check your rules for suspicious activity. If you didn't create a rule and you don't know what it does, it is probably a virus. Delete it immediately.    If your rules are not functioning, seeÂ this article.    For more information on viruses and rules, check out our other article:Â Using Outlook Rules to Find Viruses.

Tags: outlook-app Outlook-Email outlook-rules outlook-desktop creating-rules-in-outlook automate-outlook-email rules-outlook creating-rules creating-email-rules add-new-rule
Paragraphs: Each email client (such as Outlook, Gmail, or Apple Mail) has their own name and system for creating "Rules". These Rules are automated instructions the system follows, which can do a number of things.    For example, you can send emails from a specific person directly to a folder instead of the inbox, send emails containing the subject "BYU-Idaho" to a specific folder, or even place any emails that contain the word "cat" into your funny cats folder. All you need is to create Outlook Rules.    Since there are many ways to create and use Rules, this tutorial will go over one of the options. In this case, we will move all emails with the subject line "BYU-Idaho" to the folder "BYU-Idaho News".    1. Open Outlook on your desktop.    2. ClickÂ FileÂ in the top left corner.        3. ClickÂ Rules and Alerts.        4. If you have never created rules, your screen should look like this:        5. ClickÂ New Rule.        6. TheÂ Rules WizardÂ box will appear. This will provide you with some templates. Take some time to read through those to see if any of them are what you need. Remember, there are dozens of tools and options for creating rules. Use this tutorial as a guide to learning how the rules work.    7. SelectÂ Apply rule on messages I receiveÂ and clickÂ Next.        8. SelectÂ with specific words in the subject.Â In the box below, it will explain what this condition is doing. Click the linkÂ specific wordsÂ to select the name or group you wish to use. In this case, we will search for emails with the subject "BYU-Idaho".        9. Type the subject you want the computer to look for. In this case, typeÂ "BYU-Idaho".Â ClickÂ AddÂ when done.        10. ClickÂ OK.        11. SelectÂ move it to the specified folder,Â since we want to move all emails with the subject "BYU-Idaho" to the folder, "BYU-Idaho News". Then click the linkÂ specified.    Keep in mind that there are a lot of actions to choose from. You can make this as personalized as you need.        12. If you have already created the folder "BYU-Idaho News", click the folder. If you have not, clickÂ New.        13. TypeÂ BYU-Idaho NewsÂ in the box. ClickÂ OK.        14. TheÂ BYU-Idaho NewsÂ folder should be highlighted. ClickÂ OK.        15. The name of the folder and what we are looking for in the subject line should show up in the lower box.    Since we have no other parameters, clickÂ Next.        16. If you would like to make any exceptions to this action, select the ones you want. For example, if you want all emails from Windy Weather sent to your folder, except the ones with the word "tornadoes", you can make those adjustments here. When you're done, clickÂ Next.        17. Don't forget to haveÂ Turn on this ruleÂ selected, to turn on the rule. If you want this rule to happen to mail already inside your inbox, selectÂ Run this rule now on messages already inÂ "Inbox".    When you're done, clickÂ Finish.        18. You're all done! Think of all the possibilities you can do with your Rule tool! Can you see now how hackers can use these tools to create rules that hide or steal important information from you? Remember to frequently check your rules for suspicious activity. If you didn't create a rule and you don't know what it does, it is probably malware. Delete it immediately.    If your rules isn't functioning, seeÂ this article.    For more information on viruses and Rules, check out our other article:Â Using Outlook Rules to Find Viruses..

Tags: create-rules outlook-web outlook-desktop email-rules creating-email-rules add-new-rule outlook-rule-errors rule-error outlook-rule refresh-outlook outlook-login rule-not-working
Paragraphs: If you created a new rule, and it is not functioning the way you wanted it to, here are a few suggestions.    1. Check to make sure the rule you made doesn't contain any mistakes like a misspelled word or incorrectly selected action.    2. Refresh your Outlook page.    3. Log out of Outlook and log back in again.    4. If you use the web-based Outlook (where it appears as a tab on whatever Internet browser you use), having the rule apply to messages already in your inbox does not work. After you have created the rule, any new mail that comes in will function properly. If the immediate functionality of the rule is important, download the desktop version of Outlook and take a look at your rules there. The desktop version of Outlook functions normally for messages already in the inbox.

Managing email contacts    Add global contacts    1. Go to the Navigation Bar and selectÂ People.        2. Type the name of the person you wish to add into theÂ Find a ContactÂ bar or selectÂ Address BookÂ to look the person up.        3. Select the name of the person you want to add, then selectÂ Add to Contacts.    Create personal contact lists    1. Open Outlook.    2. SelectÂ New Items, and then selectÂ Group.        3. In the window that appears, enter a name and description for the group in the appropriate boxes, then clickÂ Next.        4. Type the names of contacts you would like to add in theÂ Enter names or email addressesÂ box. Once you have added all the members you wish to add, selectÂ Next.        5. Select from the list eitherÂ PublicÂ orÂ PrivateÂ for the privacy of your group. Leave the selected box next toÂ Send a copy of all group conversations...Â and clickÂ Create.        6. The contact group will be saved in yourÂ ContactsÂ folder under the name you gave it in step 4.

Tags: mass-emails bcc blind-carbon-copy email-policy mass-recipients
Paragraphs: Mass email policy    Officially, emails that consist of more than 500 recipients per message cannot be sent or received through a BYU-Idaho email account. Additionally, the BYU-Idaho account limits emails to 10,000 recipients per day. Sending a lot of emails in a short period of time to a wide list of users may qualify you for being blocked.    Even though our stated limit is 500 recipients per message and 10,000 recipients per day, Microsoft has identified a limit that we do not share to avoid spammers. If spammers were to find the Microsoft limit, they would use it to stay within the lines of credulity to bypass our security. We advise pacing your sending to a longer period or investigating using mass mailing software such as the one that University Relations utilizes in order to get a better through-rate, in addition to better analytics.    Â     Exceptions    Exceptions to this policy are intended only for explicitly-authorized senders. This includes the following:Â     Â     Procedure    When sending approved mass emails from your BYU-Idaho account or to BYU-Idaho recipients (students, faculty, staff, and alumni), campus procedure strongly encourages that you use the "bcc" (Blind Carbon Copy) option.    Â     Using Bcc    What is Bcc?    "Bcc" is the practice of sending an email to multiple recipients without disclosing the complete list of recipients.    When should I use Bcc?    You should "Bcc" when:Â     How do I send an email with Bcc?    1. When sending a new email message, selectÂ Cc.        2. In the pop-up window that appears, enter the email addresses of all recipients into theÂ BccÂ section at the bottom.        3. Once you have entered the desired email addresses, selectÂ OK.        4. Write the email andÂ selectÂ Send.

SelectÂ the drop-down arrow to expand the section.Â You will now see 2Â inbox:Â youremail@byui.eduÂ andÂ On MyÂ Computer.

Paragraphs: You canÂ archives files manually and automaticallyÂ in Outlook.Â Sometimes you will need to archive old files in Outlook in order to make room for new files while keeping the old ones accessible.Â Â     Manually Archiving Files    1. Choose the location of yourÂ archive.pstÂ file.â€¯This is the location whereâ€¯the archived emails are stored.
